column1: <body>The thesis is an individual assignment about a subject from your Master's specialisation. More information about thesis subjects, thesis supervisors and the writing process can be found on the Master thesis website.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which they can initiate and perform a literature review which is useful for their research project.

Students have knowledge of and insight into: the way in which methods and techniques of scientific research in the field of accounting, auditing, control or finance can be applied to their own research topic.
Students have knowledge of and insight into: the application of up-to-date qualitative or quantitative research methods.

Students are able to: formulate a clear research question based on relevant academic concepts and theories, and legitimized by up-to-date academic or social developments as well as to formulate hypotheses in a systematic and valid way.

Students are able to: analyse and interpret data in an accurate, reliable, comprehensive and verifiable way and to formulate conclusions which sufficiently take into account presuppositions, basic principles and the limitations/opportunities of the selected methodology.

Students are able to: report on research findings in a logical and consistent way and give a clear oral explanation of the research project as well as to answer critical questions about the research in a convincing manner.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>Het vak Materieel strafrecht borduurt voort op het B1-vak Inleiding strafrecht. In het onderhavige vak wordt dieper ingegaan op het materiële strafrecht. Het overkoepelende thema van het vak betreft ‘strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid’. Het vraagstuk wie, wanneer en waarvoor strafrechtelijk aansprakelijk is, valt uiteen in verschillende leerstukken zoals schuld, poging, deelneming en strafuitsluitingsgronden. De student doet niet alleen kennis op over de centrale begrippen en leerstukken van het materiële strafrecht, maar leert die kennis ook te gebruiken en toe te passen op een casus. Het analyseren van concrete materieel strafrechtelijke problemen (casuïstiek) vormt een belangrijk onderdeel van het vak.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• de beginselen, leerstukken en systematiek van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, herkennen, definiëren, analyseren en beoordelen;
• theoretische achtergronden, historische ontwikkelingen en maatschappelijke aspecten van het materiele strafrecht beschrijven, verklaren en analyseren;
• verschillende materieel strafrechtelijke begrippen onderscheiden, analyseren en beargumenteerd toepassen op een concrete strafrechtelijke casus;

• beoordelen welk materieel strafrechtelijk leerstuk in een concreet geval van toepassing is en motiveren of aan de in de huidige relevante wetsbepalingen, literatuur en jurisprudentie gestelde voorwaarden is voldaan, en;
• de daarvoor relevante jurisprudentie opzoeken, analyseren, toepassen en in onderling verband kritisch beoordelen.

column1: The course focuses on the strategic analysis of markets under imperfect competition, incomplete information, and incentives. It does so in a mathematical, rigorous way.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The goal of the course is twofold. First, to show how mathematics can be used to formulate and investigate economic phenomena. Second, to make students familiar with important contributions to the analysis of markets under imperfect competition, incomplete information, and incentives.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/93179,2020,Mathematical Economics (old),Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['dr. V Karamychev'],,Inhoud

The course consists of two parts.  It begins with a refreshment on classical microeconomics analysis and develops into the utility maximization theory, in Part 1.  The necessary mathematical tools (ODE) are briefly presented. The main analytical emphasis is on restoring underlying preferences from empirically observed individual behavior.

In the second, large part, the course begins with a brief introduction to Game theory and develops into the area of Bayesian games.  A few examples from the recent economic literature are studied in depth.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • To know deep functional dependencies between underlying individual preferences and empirically observed economic behaviour.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice in the presence of strategic interaction.
• To know main tools for the analysis of individual choice in the presence of private information.
• To be able to formulate the problem of recovering preferences from behavior, and to solve its simple instances.
• To be able to compute different kinds of equilibria for different types of games.
• In general, to be able to use mathematical tools for relating behavior to the underlying economic model.

column2: <title></title>

</style>

column1: <body>This Mathematics course presents the necessary Mathematical tools for analysing quantitative models that emerge from a variety of business and economic problems. The selection below reflects the scope of the studied Mathematical topics that will be useful for the analysis of economics and business problems. These topics are:

column2: • Functions and equations of one and two variables
• Sequences and series
• Financial applications
• Differentiation and optimization
• Integration
• Matrices

column1: This course lays the foundation for the quantitative courses to follow in the IBA curriculum. The scientific description and analysis of complex practical business situations often requires an analytic approach. What is usually needed is the explicit description of the transition of a system when it moves from one state to the next. Mathematics is well equipped to assist in the difficult task of describing the essential elements of such transitions. The word ""model"" is often used for the quantitative description of the specific problem in which a system finds itself at any moment in time. Working with models is a recurring activity in business studies. The process of building and analysing business models requires a Mathematical way of thinking. Therefore Mathematical skills are essential for successfully handling these business models.

IMPORTANT NOTICE: The concepts, skills, and methods from the ‘Preparation course mathematics’ are a prerequisite for this course. You will not be able to understand the course without having successfully mastered the learning goals of the preparation course.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: After completing this course, students will be able to apply the mathematical techniques covered in this course and to build, analyze and solve mathematical models emerging from business problems using mathematical techniques from the course and interpret the solutions in terms of the original problem. A detailed list of learning goals per learning unit is available in the document ‘Material overview’ in the ‘Course Information’ on Canvas.

column1: The course is based on online modules, which provide the theory and practice exercises. Each week, optional question hours are scheduled where you can ask questions about the material. There is a midterm and final exam. This set-up offers a high flexibility (no lectures or tutorials), and relies primarily on self-study. This version of the course is intended for students that have a considerable proficiency in mathematics.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>At the end of the course, students will

column2: • Have acquired mathematical skills that support more quantitative courses in EUC

• Be able to deal with mathematics in such a way that in later years a student will be able to recognize which subject from mathematics is used and – if necessary – to study more advanced topics by her/himself.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. Traditionally, HTA researchers and health economists have concentrated on health outcomes expressed in QALYs when attempting to measure the benefits from health care products or programs. There is growing recognition, however, that patient preferences for health care products and programs are also shaped by non-health outcomes (such as amount of information) and process attributes (such as treatment location, or route of drug administration). Studies into these outcomes beyond health are an emerging trend in HTA and health economics. Discrete choice experiments (DCEs) are typically used for this purpose. DCE allows investigation of many types of research questions, as it is an attribute-based measure of benefit, which gives this method the flexibility to include any concern deemed of relevance. This course provides a resource for students in the health sector who want to familiarize themselves with assessment of patient preferences using DCEs. We present the fundamental principles and theory underlying DCEs, demonstrate the process of carrying out a choice study, and discuss the policy implications of the results.

Course materials will be studied in lectures and work groups, but students will also be actively involved in a DCE study with the aim to increase understanding of what is taught more quickly. Small groups will carry out a DCE study on a topic that is theirs to choose. Part of the work will be done during the work groups, and feedback will be provided continuously. The groups complete their work step by step over several weeks. The group's work will be evaluated on the basis of a short report about the DCE; individual members of the group may receive different grades based on their contributions.
The written examination is 70% of the final grade (minimum grade 5.0 or higher). The remainder derives from the group project (30%).
The re-sit is composed as a written examination (70%) and a group project (30%).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, students will be able to:

column2: • recognize the importance of patient preference measurements in health care
• describe the theoretical foundation(s) of discrete choice experiments (DCEs)
• develop their own DCE using state-of-the-art (publishable) methods
• understand recent articles in the DCE literature and assess the validity of the presented conclusions

column1: <body>Many individuals use many forms of media for many hours every day of their lives. In this course, we examine the different appropriation and interpretation of media that can be observed in different media audiences and their uses and influence of media on daily life. The course will present different schools of thought that study audiences and potential effects of media, such as: symbolic interactionism; uses and gratifications; media effects, critical and cultural studies; and relational perspectives of communication. Examples we will study include: social media, fandoms, newsmedia, propaganda, gender and sexuality, violence in media, and videogames, among others. In addition to reading contemporary communication and media research and contributing to class discussions, students have weekly assignments to ensure all the students prepared and reflected on theories and findings. A final individual assignment will require the student to write a critical essay analyzing a media product and its audiences according to the concepts learned in class.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92326,2020,Media Campaigns,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This seminar addresses the theory and practice of media campaigns as well as processes that drive the planning and execution of these campaigns and the role of the latest technological advancements in campaigning. Students will review theories and research on segmentation, media use and persuasion and will analyze real-world media campaigns by drawing on the theoretical and research articles covered in the course.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key concepts and approaches in theory and research on media campaigns
• The role and use of (different) media in various types of campaigns.
• The complexities of persuasion within media campaigns.
• Cultural dimensions of media campaigns in different countries and social backgrounds.
• Explain the major components of media campaigns, the primary outcome variables, and the individual difference and social psychological variable associated with message receivers.
• Analyze and critique the effectiveness of media campaigns within a business, health, or political context.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: In media studies, research tends to focus on the output of media industries. In this course, we take another perspective by investigating the economic characteristics of media markets and the strategic behavior of media firms on them. How did Facebook come to dominate the social media market? How are incumbent TV broadcasters responding to the challenges posed by Youtube and Netflix? In order to study these and other questions, we will address key media economic theoretical traditions, learn how to define markets, discuss the particular characteristics of media products and investigate the fast changes in media. After this, we will use media management literature to understand how media firms are responding to economic structures, product characteristics and market changes.  We will take an explicit international perspective, using case studies from many different parts of the world. In these case studies, we will study how the specific economic characteristics of the media product and societal and economic context within it is offered, affected the strategic management decisions that were made. Students are also required to conduct a case study themselves of a media firm’s behavior in its defined market.

column2: <title></title>

• Major theoretical perspectives and key concepts in media economics.

• Analyze media products, media firms and media markets from an economic for-profit perspective.
• Take an international perspective on media economic research.
• Conduct case study research on media firms and their products.
• Formulate the implications of media economic analyses for strategic management decisions of media firms.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92288,2020,Media Entrepreneurship,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. S Horst'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The phenomenon of entrepreneurship is closely connected with a growing mediatization of organizations and society. In this way, media facilitate various creative processes and enables individuals and organizations to develop new ideas, facilitate new processes and build new ventures. At the same time, media entrepreneurship is a very young, but rapidly growing research area with a variety of backgrounds, concepts and methodological opportunities.

Therefore, the aims of this course are threefold. First, we aim to provide an overview of the field of media entrepreneurship and intend to spark critical investigations and shared discussions around its meaning. What is media entrepreneurship? What kind of styles, habits and practices can we see in different empirical settings? Second, we will explore current practices of entrepreneurship in the media and creative industries. How can we use media in creative manner to generate new opportunities and create sustainable organizational responses to the challenges we face? Third: These questions will be explored dialogically and creatively around different empirical phenomena in media entrepreneurship, for example through small research activities such as conducting market research or qualitative interviews with practitioners and analyzing these in class for further reflection.

This course introduces students to the major theoretical approaches in the study of mass mediated communication, drawing on research examples that cover various media (e.g. radio, television, film, newspapers, magazines, and the internet) and different countries. The course provides a historical and critical overview of theory and research on processes of media production, media contents, and media reception. The impact media have on culture and society is explored as well as debates that circulate about the media and media influences.
Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussion of student assignments and coursework.</body>

column1: Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:

column2: • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of mass mediated communication

• Articulate and develop their own viewpoints and research questions,using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92207,2020,Media Industries: Trends and Strategies,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>

column1: Media industries have experienced radical changes in recent years as a result of new digital technologies and distribution platforms (e.g. gaming, the internet, mobile platforms etc.). For companies, workers and policymakers operating within media industries, these changes have severely impacted their operations: previously separated media markets have converged, new media products and business models have been developed, and users are no longer passive consumers but are actively peer producing content (so called user generated content). This seemingly chaotic period media industries find themselves in is the starting point of this course.

During the course, students will familiarize themselves with the latest trends and developments in the media industries. We will start with theoretical foundations that are crucial for understanding and researching media industries and media innovation. We will then turn our attention to trends in the media industries, and discuss how these trends impact the strategic behavior of industry actors (companies, audiences, policymakers). In addition to discussing literature, we will also use guest lectures and online material (e.g. videos) to discuss trends and strategies within the media sector.

column2: • The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

• Key analytical tools to define and study media industries
• Key analytical tools to define and study media innovation
• Reflect critically on the theoretical viewpoints and research materials presented in class
• Critically reflect upon developments in media industries and assess their impact and newness.
• Analyse current developments and strategies in the media industries using theories and concepts covered in the course

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92283,2020,Media Policies and Markets,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['PM Leendertse, MA']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Governments have always had a special interest in media markets. Their policies and regulation can have a great impact on the boundaries within which media organizations can operate. Governmental scrutiny of media is often justified by societal expectations that countries have of their media sector. The fast-paced changes in the media industry have forced governments around the world to reassess their media policy. For instance, the scandal around Cambridge Analytica’s usage of Facebook users’ data has forced many governments to rethink their privacy regulations.

During this course, we will use models from (media) economics and institutional economics to conceptualize the interplay between government policy and media markets. In addition, we will focus on theories and developments around policy and regulation that allow us to analyze, critically assess and contextualize media policy.

The seminar connects relevant issues within media policy to relevant theoretical concepts. From examples on fake news to hate speech and violation of data privacy. We will discuss these and other developments in media policy using practical and international examples. Furthermore, we will try to formulate alternative policy options that governments could have taken. The seminar is participative in nature, which means that students are required to prepare the lecture, participate in discussions, debate and give presentations.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the interplay between media markets, media firms and governmental policy
• relevant theories to analyze media policy
• the most important international developments in media policy for media markets (e.g. privacy, copyrights, market power, freedom of speech)
• global differences in media policy traditions
• analyse media policy
• reflect critically on relevant theory and developments in media policy
• analyse and critically evaluate different policy options
• assess the impact of governmental policy on media markets

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: A decade ago, a travel agent was a legitimate job. Today, this line of employment has become redundant with online sites such as kayak, priceline and expedia that allow customers to shop virtually for competitive pricing. This new platform economy creates new questions regarding how algorithms shape the competitiveness of the travel and tourism industry and to what extent does this allow for a level playing field for companies in this sector. Further, the rise of the middle class in countries like India and China are producing new user groups that pushes tourism-related companies to rethink their advertising, city branding and packaging strategies that can best tailor to these new demographics.

In fact, across industries we see disruptions taking place with the rise of digital media, novel technologies and platforms, new data policies, governance measures, and new user groups. These trends demand that we reflect and rethink the ways in which these industries are being transformed and the repercussions on the future of work and wellbeing for our societies. This captures not just a shift in the nature of employment, but possibly the  birth of a new worldview, corporate ideology, management, and customer relations strategy where certain intermediaries have become digital.

This course will focus on case studies from diverse sectors including healthcare, marketing, and education and how the data economies are manifesting within these specific industries. Students will explore the global and political infrastructures at play as technology companies, laborers, user groups, and governance structures span across nations, complicating our understandings of a typical business today. We will jointly explore urgent ethical challenges, serious sustainability concerns, and dominant global trends in user behaviors, company practices, and national policies that pushes for a design thinking approach to “good” organizational practice.

Overall, the intent of this course is to gain a more critical perspective on the role of digital media and datafication in different industries  in order to shape more inclusive, ethical and sustainable business models and practices in this digital and global age.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Create an argumentation on contemporary concerns, issues, and challenges on datafication and digitization pertaining to a specific industry.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92210,2020,Media and Consumer Culture,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. SJ Opree'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Advertising, materialism, and consumption are central aspects of modern societies across the globe. Contemporary societies are intertwined with consumer culture and marked by peoples continuously growing wants and needs, as well as the conspicuous consumption of mass produced and marketed goods. This course provides a psycho-cultural perspective on consumer culture, and advertising and branded space in particular. We examine the history of advertising, the commercial and social aspects of the messages conveyed by ads, and the advertising industry's influence on social relations and institutions such as politics. Furthermore, we discuss the various ways in marketing to classify consumers, such as the Values and Lifestyle Typology – and learn that individuals differ greatly in their (susceptibility to) consumer values.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 50. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92575,2020,Media and Governance,Engels,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. RFI Moody', 'prof.dr. EH Klijn']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Complex governance processes in networks are constantly influenced by the outside world. This is especially happening through the media attention and the dynamics this generates in networks. Media have become a separate institution with its own logic (the media logic) and its own rules how to bring news and package it. Media logic is concerned with the content of the news provided as well as the formats in which news is created and processed. The format of an item on the television news bulletin for instance, has to meet certain criteria: the slot allocated for the story is only a few minutes long, it has to have news value and it should attract or keep the attention of the viewers. These criteria influence how reality is constructed in the news story.

column3: Many authors claim that media have profound influence on our daily social life, how policy problems are shaped and on various other institutions in society. And this becomes visible when media pay attention to governance processes. Not only does the visibility of these processes enhance but also the decision dynamics change considerably as agenda forming theories have been arguing for some time.

The mediatized world asks for public leaders who can communicate their messages in clear “sound bites,” who can adapt swiftly to new developments and “media hypes,” and who can create attractive brands which arouse positive associations with citizens and voters. But in this public leaders in modern network society are faced with a growing gap between the front stage of a mediatized political world on the one hand and the daily practical life of complexity of governance processes in networks on the other hand (the backstage).

In this course we explore the media as a separate institution, their influence on policy processes and the requirements it posed on public managers. But we also explore managerial strategies that public managers have to influence media attention, like (political) public relations, and public branding.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: <li>

column4: <li>

column5: Explaining what relevant developments are in the relation between media, public administration and society

column4: <li>

column5: Analyzing different aspects of these developments by using concrete examples.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Migration has been a characteristic of societies for centuries. Humans have always migrated to either escape harsh lives, search for better ones, or both. Continuing immigration flows and increasing diversity in many societies have led to more complex processes of integration and the emergence of so-called transnationalism, a phenomenon characterized by cross-border engagements of migrants, organizations and institutions, as well as multiple embeddings of migrants in their (new) homelands. In this course,  we  focus on  the  critical  role  played by media  and communication  in  the  different levels of the transnational condition of migration, ranging from mass media representations of migrants and refugees to the mediated communication exchanges conducted in digital spaces, from interactions between relevant stakeholders in the field of NGOs and policy-making through the political and economic side of migrants’ lives to the role played by hands-on intercultural mediation projects.

This course aims to offer a platform for students to develop their research skills for making sense of the intricate relationships between media and migration across different sociopolitical and cultural contexts (Western and non-Western) and drivers of migration (e.g., economic, political, cultural, humanitarian, environmental). In eight weeks, students will work on their own research project, covering topics related to migration, media and technology. Research projects involve using theories and empirical analyses based on in-depth interview research, contacting migration actors, practicing intercultural skills training for conducting research and/or working in this field, among others. Throughout this process, students will gain conceptual, empirical and practical knowledge for their master thesis projects.

column1: The research workshop Media and Migration is oriented towards MA students who are interested in developing theoretical, empirical and practical (applied) projects in the field of media and migration, and intercultural communication. This course aims to offer conceptual, empirical and practical tools for building students’ knowledge about current (research) topics and trends in this interdisciplinary field that can also be used in the development of students' master thesis projects.

column2: • Current theoretical perspectives and key concepts in the study of media and migration.
• Qualitative methodologies in research on media and migration.
• Ethical issues and procedures in research involving migrant populations.
• The experiences of migrants in relation to communication practices and networks that involve digital media.
• Design and execute a small-scale in-depth interview study on the topic of migrants and the media.
• Report and present their preliminary and conclusive findings in oral and written form.
• Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research.

column1: This course analyzes the close and multifaceted relationship between media and politics. It is largely through the media that citizens develop an idea of what the world of politics looks like and how it operates. All media are influential in this respect: not just broadcast news, newspapers, and current event magazines, but also (fictional) films and novels, and, increasingly, blogs and social media. Traditional media enable politicians, government officials, and other political actors to simultaneously reach millions of people. New technologies, in turn, intensify the possibilities of citizens themselves to engage politically with one another and to directly challenge politicians and authorities. Fictional media, finally, play an important role in letting us re-live, criticize and imagine politics beyond our everyday experiences. With this encompassing view of the relationship between media and politics in mind, we will pay special attention to politicians, journalists, and citizens/audiences, their interactions and the ways in which these interactions impact democracy. We will discuss different strategies through which politicians and other public figures try to turn the media into their allies, even at the expense of democratic values. We will also analyze journalistic practices and products, approaching them as responses to sometimes diverging interests, including those of politicians, audiences, and media organizations. Finally, we will ponder on political communication's alleged contributions to citizens' re- and/or de-politicization.
Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:

column2: • Key normative claims about the media in democratic societies.
• The relationships between media institutions and political institutions in international perspective.
• The roles of political reporters and other media professionals, politicians, and citizens in political communication processes.
• The forces and processes that shape political media content in specific ways.
• The effects of media coverage on citizen political attitudes and behavior, as well as the possibilities of citizens in shaping these effects.
• Recognize and articulate political communication concepts as they relate to different media content they encounter.
• Read, critique, and apply major political communication concepts to questions about media and society.
• Build arguments that synthesize and integrate knowledge about the relationship between media and politics.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92262,2020,Media and Social-Cultural Change,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. I Awad Cherit'],,"Inhoud

column1: The idea that the media (can) have the power to change society and culture is at least as old as propaganda and censorship. And yet, questions about the relationship between media and socio- cultural change continue to be at the core of much communication and media research today. How does this relationship look like? (When) Do the media simply reflect social-change? (When) Can they also facilitate change? Do certain media genres, platforms, or media production models lend themselves to more conservative or revolutionary goals than others? What roles do people—activists, producers, and members of the audience, for example—play in this? How has the power of the media changed, especially in the last decades and with new technologies?

This course uncovers the complexities behind these questions and explores answers offered in the academic literature, as well as the practical experiences and views of individuals who work in the media and in the promotion of social change. In order to interpret and assess these answers, experiences and views, we rely on theories from communication and media studies, as well as social theory more generally. We pay special attention, for example, to ideology and hegemony, to (journalistic) objectivity, mediatization, media/technological determinism, structure and agency. Since the relationship between the media and socio- cultural change is not only complicated, but also fluid and context-specific, the course adopts a historical and cross-national perspective. Course activities include group projects, active participation in the course blog, and a final essay.

• Different ways in which media stimulate or hinder socio-cultural change.

• Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.

• Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies and in their own work.

column1: In deze module staat ondernemerschap in de mediasector in het algemeen en in de journalistiek in het bijzonder centraal. We kijken naar bestaande en nieuwe businessmodellen, van zowel grote bedrijven, van jonge startups als van individuele professionals. Tijdens de module lezen studenten literatuur over deze businessmodellen, verdiepen zich in onderzoek op dit terrein en gaan in discussie met gastsprekers over inzichten uit de praktijk. Thema’s als platformisering freelance journalistiek, content marketing en crowdfunding passeren de revue. De module heeft als doel inzichten uit de theorie te verbinden met de actuele praktijk. Via deze weg leren we over de mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen voor bedrijven en professionals. Tevens komen de maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen aan bod, zoals de toenemende vervaging van grenzen tussen journalistiek, amusement, voorlichting en PR.

• De verschillen tussen theoretische en praktische kennis op dit terrein;
• De mogelijkheden en beperkingen van verschillende businessmodellen;
• De maatschappelijke implicaties van deze businessmodellen.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course will examine key issues across Latin American Media. It strives to provide with a panorama of what is happening across the continent and examine the role of media in politics, and its relationship to national identity and state building. The sessions will discuss on a country basis; the build-up of national media production and the flow of media, into, across and out of Latin America; as well as the evolution of key genres, like the telenovela, that have come to be identified with Latin America. Theoretically, we will examine approaches that have originated in Latin America: hybridity, dependency, imperialism, globalization, as well as, the development of geo-cultural and cultural- linguistic regions. An element of this course will include watching and discussing media from the region, as well as evaluations made in and outside the region. Specialists from different areas of the region will provide lectures in order to explore more closely the link among the media formats, contents and the changing social realities in the Latin-American region.</body>

column1: <body>This course focuses on children's media use and on parents and educators who raise their children to media-literate persons. The child's media-landscape will be discussed together with theories on how the media may influence children. Next the role of parents will be discussed. Parents can use various strategies to further positive media effects such as learning, or dampen negative effects such as fear reactions or aggression. Students will be stimulated to explore and think about their own experiences and ideas on the strategies that parents use with traditional media as television and  cinema movies, and with modern media such as computers, game consoles, smart phones, and tablets. Furthermore, we will look at tools that exist for parents, such as rating systems (Kijkwijzer and PEGI), technical safety applications on the computer, and several information and advice sources,  such as Common Sense Media. The final goal of this course is a to propose a practical tool for supporting parents in guiding their children’s media use.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

• Critically reflect upon different academic perspectives and theories on parental mediation.
• Independently apply these in their own writings and (desk)research.
• Present their ideas on parental mediation to an audience of fellow students.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92261,2020,Media, Culture and Globalisation",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. AJC van der Hoeven'],,"Inhoud

column1: This course focuses on the key role of the media and cultural industries in the international spread of culture. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past decades witnessed a significant intensification of international cultural flows. Among other reasons, this is a consequence of the introduction of new media technologies and the rise of multinational conglomerates in the media and cultural industries.

We will explore different theoretical approaches to examine the relationship between globalisation in the media and cultural industries, and the symbolic meaning of media products. Furthermore, during the weekly sessions of this course, we will discuss themes such as global cities, multiculturalism, global media events and cosmopolitanism. Both the meetings and the assignments will pay ample attention to the future of globalisation. We will use scenario-building techniques to explore the future connections between media, culture and globalisation. In these activities, theories about globalisation will be applied to societal and organisational problems.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Key developments in the global spread of culture and the role of media therein.
• Different perspectives in the scholarly and public debate on the nature and impact of cultural globalisation.
• Apply relevant theoretical insights and methods in the analysis of globalisation processes and their social consequences.
• Critically reflect on academic texts, both verbal and in written form.
• Design and write an essay; make an academic argument.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/96165,2020,Media, Games, and Creative Industry",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. LA Borges Lima'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: “But do you play games all day for work?” is a question faced by many academics in the realm of play, game, and videogame studies. Indeed, playing, and notably meaningful play, is a major component of such area, but not all there is to it. In this seminar, we invite you to explore the object of games – digital or not – in the encounter of media studies and the creative industry. The course is divided into three parts - production, content, and consumption – that aim to encompass the main characteristics of these different media and their central role in the creative industries. In production, we look at game developers and publishers, independent creators and groundbreaking game auteurs such as Shigeru Miyamoto (father of Mario and Luigi), and Hideo Kojima (Metal Gear Solid; Death Stranding), among others. You will learn the complex inner workings of the games industries and its employees. In the content part, we delve deep into matters of social, political and cultural contexts within games, present in their narratives and mechanics. We discuss examples such as the representation of War in board games and digital games; gender and sexuality in RPG’s; and fantasy and mental health. Lastly, in the consumption part, we turn our attention to players and their myriad of playful experiences. We explore matters related to fandom; online communities such as Reddit; online and couch play; affect, identification and emotion.

The course, although academic in nature, is an opportunity to engage both with the application of concepts into everyday media production, and the workers of games industry. As such, students will deliver assignments that include production of vlogging and gameplay, and an in-depth journalistic review of a videogame in either written or audiovisual form. Due to the nature of the topic, the course is comprised of both academic readings, popularly produced content (e.g. gameplays, journalistic reviews/game analysis, podcasts), and in-class/off-class play and game activities.</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94081,2020,Mediation advocacy: theory and practice,Engels,Erasmus School of Law,,['dr. AJ de Roo', 'dr. RW Jagtenberg']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In Western society, law students are led to believe that in-court adjudication is the self-evident and thus normal method for settling disputes. This conception, however, is far away from everyday reality. Apart from the fact that many disputes do not lend themselves to authoritative yes-or-no decisions, disputants may experience a series of problems when they choose to assert their rights in court, such as costs, delays, proof proceedings, uncertainty and unpredictability. Where bilateral negotiations are deadlocked and the resourcefulness of a third party is sought, other methods of dispute settlement than adjudication are therefore increasingly considered by disputants, particularly in areas such as construction, employment and family disputes.

Mediation and other modes of dispute resolution such as conciliation, Med.Arb., mini trial, fact finding, all belong to the A(lternative) D(ispute) R(esolution)-family. These methods tend to focus on the parties’ real interests and their future relationships. Possible legal problems relating to ADR are discussed such as the compatibility of ADR with the Right of Access to Court, and the legal status of mediated settlements. In addition, national and European developments on court-annexed mediation shall be highlighted. In this context, the outcomes of inter alia the Dutch national mediation project shall be discussed. Practical training is provided through role plays and other practical exercises, which are essential for a proper and profound understanding of the working of mediation – definitely for those who pursue a career in law practice.
Over the last decades, mediation has become one of the typical services provided by law practitioners. Obviously, law graduates should be abreast of this development, which is here to stay.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The aim of this course is to give the participating student an understanding of the wide variety of dispute settlement processes, with an emphasis on mediation advocacy. After completion of the course the student should be able to distinguish the various modes of dispute resolution, in particular from the perspective of a lawyer assisting client-disputants.
The student shall be assessed on area related knowledge and analytical skills.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/98836,2020,Mediation, Moderation, and Conditional Process Modeling",Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. I Evangelidis'],,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Mediation topics include: 1) simple mediation with any type of independent and dependent variables (i.e., continuous, dichotomous, multicategorical), 2) mediation with multiple parallel mediators, 3) mediation with multiple serial mediators. Moderation topics include: 1) moderation models with up to 2 moderators (3-way interactions) using any type of independent and dependent variables, 2) analysis of unconditional versus conditional effects, 3) Model estimation and interpretation, 4) Visualization. I will also discuss how to analyze conditional process models (i.e., models that include both mediation and moderation). Depending on the pace of the course I will also try to cover some specialized topics such as mediation analysis in within-participants designs and mediation analysis using a binary mediator. The course will be focused on teaching you how to conduct the appropriate analysis and interpret your results. We will be using PROCESS (Hayes, 2018) for the purposes of this course. Attendants should have a recent version of SPSS and PROCESS (preferably 3.5) installed on their computer.
This course is taught by Dr Ioannis Evangelidis (ESADE Business School, Ramon Llull University).</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: In this course you will learn how to conduct and interpret the results of mediation, moderation, and conditional process analyses. Mediation describes the case where an independent variable X influences another variable M (mediator), which in turn influences the dependent variable Y. For example, giving time to others (X) has been shown to enhance one’s own feelings of competence (M), which in turn leads to the feeling that one has more time available (Y), (Mogilner, Chance, and Norton 2012). Moderation describes the case where the effect of the independent variable X on the dependent variable Y changes across different levels of another variable M (moderator). For instance, perceived conflict between goals (X) makes consumers feel that they have less time available (Y) and this effect is further moderated by breathing speed (M). When consumers are nudged to breathe slowly the negative effect of perceived goal conflict on feelings of time is reduced (Etkin, Evangelidis, and Aaker 2015). Conditional process models combine mediation with moderation.

This is an applied course: knowledge of algebra is not required. However, a basic understanding of OLS regression is necessary. This course is targeted to any person doing social science research that wants to learn how to test for mediation and moderation in his or her data.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/90329,2020,Medical Demography (HS04),Engels,Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC),,['dr. J.A. Haagsma', 'dr. W.J. Nusselder']",,

<body>Is euthanasia of demented patients in a progressed state morally permissible? When should doctors refuse requests for new technologies of assisted reproduction, such as in vitro fertilisation (IVF)? Do we have a moral duty to fund orphan drugs? What should government, industry and individuals do in order to tackle problems like obesity or organ donation? Are new technologies to enhance the capabilities of human beings (such as cognition, social behaviour and mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Are patients with diverse cultural and ethnical background treated equally in the clinic?  Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this course, we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. In the first part of the course, the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent) will be introduced. In the second part of the course, the obtained knowledge will be applied to issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.</body>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; mood, or physical appearance) morally desirable? Medical ethics and public health ethics are interesting and complex fields of study. In this module we study pressing ethical issues and how theoretical approaches, concepts and methods may help us to deal with these issues. The first couple of meetings are devoted to the most important theoretical approaches (utilitarianism, deontology, and virtue ethics) and concepts in ethics and medical ethics (e.g. autonomy, paternalism, informed consent). Next, we will focus on issues in medicine and public health care and critically reflect on central arguments including the influence of hidden assumptions and technological developments.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Upon completion of this course students will have the ability to:

column4: <li>

column5: identify and analyse moral problems in medical and public health ethics, notably on issues concerning medically assisted reproduction, end-of-life decisions, organ donation, enhancement technologies, public health measures, and justice in health care;

column4: <li>

column5: analyse, criticize and relate core concepts (e.g. autonomy, competence, informed consent, paternalism, justice, responsibility for health etc) to practical debates;

column4: <li>

column5: to explain how (anthropological) assumptions play a role in the moral debate;

column4: <li>

column5: argue for particular points of view in concrete problem cases and to acknowledge the strength and weakness of relevant arguments;

column4: <li>

column5: evaluate their own ethical beliefs and justify their recommended courses of action.

column2: </body>

column1: This course deals with the vast and important area of memory. Memory forms the basis for much of human cognition and behavior. We use our memory not only to remember the groceries we have to buy at the supermarket or to remember where and when to meet a friend, we also need our memory to engage in a conversation, to make calculations, to recognize loved ones, and even to ski downhill. In other words, memory plays an essential role in our daily lives. This becomes even more evident when we consider patients who have severe memory disorders caused by an accident or disease.
The course addresses cognitive and biological aspects of human memory. The following topics will be discussed.
The Neural Basis of Memory and Memory Disorders

column1: <div>This course has the following learning objectives:

column2: • At the end of the course students have intermediate knowledge of the most important empirical findings and theories of short-term/working memory.

• At the end of the course students have intermediate knowledge of the most important empirical findings and theories of long-term memory (including semantic and implicit memory tasks and skill learning).
• At the end of the course students have a basic understanding of some important mathematical models of human memory.
• At the end of the course students have basic knowledge of the biological basis of human memory and memory disorders.
• At the end of the course students have the elementary skills needed to critically evaluate claims in research papers.

column1: Corporate takeovers are one of the most important corporate events. Furthermore, during the takeover process firms encounter several challenges, such as legal, cultural, and regulatory hurdles. Overall, the argument to take over another firm must be very compelling. However, takeovers intensify agency problems between the stakeholders, most importantly between the management and the shareholders. This course focuses on the role of corporate governance with special emphasis on the context of takeovers or mergers and acquisitions (M&A).

The goal of this course is to provide students with a general understanding of corporate governance mechanisms within the firm. It also highlights the importance of corporate governance in the context of M&As. Furthermore, the course combines theory, empirical evidence, and practitioners’ views on topics at the intersection of accounting, M&A, and corporate governance. Guest lectures throughout the course provide students with the unique opportunity to gain insights from and engage in discussions with specialists from the field.

After participating in this course we hope that you improve your decision making by recognizing that corporate governance plays a crucial part in takeover activities as well as in the functioning of the firm by reducing agency conflicts stemming from the separation of ownership and control.

column1: ​On completion of this course, students should be able to:
1.    Explain and understand the firm’s corporate governance structure
2.    Be aware of how corporate governance can affect management behaviour
3.    Understand how corporate governance plays a role in M&As
4.    Apply basic concepts of accounting and valuation within the context of M&As
5.    Have gained insights into selected topics (guest lectures) from specialists in the field of M&A, accounting and corporate governance</body>

column1: body { font-size: 9pt;A world. Specifically, you should be able to answer questions such as: Overall, do M&As pay? What are the various motivations for M&As? When do M&As make sense? What are the drivers of M&A waves? How does one value a M&A deal? What is the M&A process? What is the appropriate M&A risk management strategy? What does it take to make the ""synergy"" come to life? When do leveraged buy-outs make sense, and how can they be financed? etc.

The general objectives are that 1) although you may know nothing about M&A before taking the course, after taking the course you will have a broad and solid understanding of all important aspects of M&A, and 2) after taking the course you will have good knowledge of how M&A works from both theoretical and practical perspectives, and will be able to act as an analyst and analyze/evaluate/solve a real-world M&A transaction.

column1: This course is intended to enhance the M&A preparedness of students in their future roles as employees, M&A advisors, or stakeholders by providing an overview of topics relating to M&A, especially, the major accounting and valuation related aspects. The first module of the course will focus on the various rational and (sub-rational) motives / drivers of mergers (or takeovers), the sources of value creation and the determinants of deal structuring, payment and financing choices. The second module will cover some of the important accounting challenges and discuss various valuation related aspects in the context of M&A. In the final module, we will discuss risk management in the context of M&A and the challenges associated with post-merger integration. The course will combine academic content with practical insights that are provided by invited guest speakers.

»    Be able to estimate financial value creation from the deal.
»    Have an overview of academic evidence relating to different aspects of M&A.</body>

column1: This course introduces framing theory and discusses its relevance for media and communication studies. The lectures focus on framing theory and discuss practical challenges in message framing and persuasion.

This course teaches students how organisations (private and public), the news media, and audiences interact through public relations and how communication professionals strategically frame their messages. This has a theoretical and a practical dimension. In the theoretical part, students learn what framing in the media is: The modern public sphere builds on dynamic media technologies and complex networks of media- and communication organisations. Audiences learn about current issues and important developments in business, culture, and society through different types of media. Modern communications- and PR professionals need to understand the complex interplay of content (language and visuals), technology (channels and formats) and relationships between relevant stakeholders (the target audience, key media outlets, and other organisations) that underlie and shape framing processes. A successful combination of content, technology, and relationships with media organisations can make a profound impact on how audiences perceive a particular message, i.e., pick up on its framing.

Understanding this process eventually enables communication experts to design and execute effective campaigns that build up, reinforce, enhance, or repair an organization’s public reputation. Practical use cases include e.g., product/campaign launches, policy implementations, or crisis management. In the practice-oriented part of the course, students learn how to frame issues through strategic communication in written and spoken word, using modern technology (mainly via a press kit and press conference).

Public and private organisations are often at the center of news reporting in diverse contexts. It is essential for communication professionals to have in-depth knowledge about how public communication and framing in the media work in a digital society, so that they can represent their organisation strategically and result oriented.

column1: De cursus omvat twee luiken die op elkaar afgestemd worden: een logisch luik en een systematisch luik.

In het logische luik bestuderen we de predicatenlogica. We beschouwen dan ook redeneringen waarvan de correctheid niet alleen steunt op de betekenis van de voegtekens maar ook op de betekenis van de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één"". We onderscheiden het semantische begrip “geldig gevolg van” en het syntactische begrip “afleidbaar uit” en bestuderen de relatie tussen deze twee begrippen.

In het systematische luik worden de centrale problemen uit formele ontologie en de analytische metafysica aan de orde gesteld: universalia, substanties, tijd, compositie, persistentie, causaliteit, responsafhankelijkheid en wereldbeelden.

Studenten mogen één werkcollege missen. Indien ze meerdere werkcolleges missen, moeten er ter compensatie opgaven gemaakt worden die bij het (de) gemiste werkcollege(s) horen en welke beoordeeld worden. Het tentamenonderdeel dat overeenkomt met de gemiste werkcolleges zal beoordeeld worden met het laagste cijfer behaald voor (i) de compenserende opgaven (ii) de tentamenopgaven behorende bij de gemiste werkcolleges.

</style>

column1: 1.. De student is vertrouwd met de formele taal van de predicaten logica (welke naast de logische voegtekens de kwantoren “voor alle"" en “er is minstens één bevat), bekend met de (beperkte) uitdrukkingskracht van deze formele taal en in staat om alledaagse deductieve argumenten te vertalen naar de taal van de predicaten logica.

2. De student is vertrouwd met Tarski’s waarheidsdefinitie voor de taal van de predicaten logica en gerelateerde noties zoals model, vervulbaarheid, vrije en gebonden variabele en in staat om, gebruik makend van deze noties, (alledaagse) argumenten op hun geldigheid te beoordelen.

3.  De student is vertrouwd met een tableau (afleidings-) systeem voor de predicatenlogica en in staat om dit systeem  te gebruiken om na te gaan of een argument (on)geldig is en, indien een argument ongeldig is, een tegenvoorbeeld te construeren.

4. De student is vertrouwd met enkele toepassingen van (het modelbegrip uit) de predicaten logica in de analytische filosofie, met name in de analytische metafysica, en in staat om zich hier kritisch tot te verhouden.
5. De student kan standpunten formuleren en onderbouwen betreffende ontische, ontologische en metafysische onderwerpen

6. De student kan zelf aspecten van wereldbeelden ontrafelen, uitwerken, in relatie brengen tot klassieke, ontische, ontologische en metafysische denkbeelden en teksten, en er zich kritisch toe verhouden
7. De student kan de belangrijkste auteurs, begrippen, distincties, en theorieën uit de metafysica identificeren, omschrijven, vergelijken en toepassen.</body>

<body>Het vak Inleiding methoden en technieken biedt een eerste kennismaking met de belangrijkste manieren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek die in de criminologie worden gebruikt. Tijdens de onderwijsgroepen en de hoorcolleges wordt aandacht besteed aan onderwerpen en begrippen die van belang zijn om goed sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek te kunnen herkennen en zelf uit te kunnen voeren. Gedacht kan worden aan het formuleren van de probleemstelling, het bepalen van het onderzoeksontwerp (ook wel design genoemd), het kiezen van de methoden van data verzamelen, het operationaliseren van concepten, het kiezen van de technieken om de data te analyseren, de interpretatie van de bevindingen en het doen van uitspraken ten behoeve van de beantwoording van de probleemstelling. Zowel kwantitatief als kwalitatief onderzoek komen bij het vak aan de orde. Tijdens de practica gaan de studenten zelf oefenen met het uitvoeren van sociaalwetenschappelijk onderzoek. Tijdens de kwantitatieve practica wordt met verschillende kwantitatieve analysetechnieken in SPSS geoefend. Ook zijn er kwalitatieve practicumbijeenkomsten waarin de studenten (in kleine groepen) zullen gaan oefenen met interviewvaardigheden.</body>

column1: In dit tweede methodevak van de opleiding Criminologie wordt de kennis uit Inleiding methoden en technieken verdiept en worden meer toepassingen aangeleerd in het verzamelen en analyseren van kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve gegevens. Na afloop van dit vak is de student er klaar voor om zijn eerste eigen onderzoek te gaan uitvoeren.

In het kwantitatieve gedeelte van het vak ligt de focus op het analyseren van data. Na de beschrijvende analyses die in Inleiding methoden en technieken zijn behandeld worden nu methoden geleerd om (complexe) samenhang tussen variabelen te analyseren. Daarbij gaan we uitgebreid in op situaties waarbij meer dan twee kenmerken onderling samenhangen (multivariate analyse).

In het kwalitatieve gedeelte van het vak wordt onderzoek gedaan naar jeugdsubculturen aan de hand van interviews en observaties. Vervolgens wordt geleerd hoe kwalitatieve onderzoekers hun gegevens analyseren. Tevens worden ethische problemen besproken en de manier waarop onderzoekers hun subjectieve persoonlijke veldwerkervaringen kunnen aanwenden bij het beter begrijpen van het onderwerp dat ze onderzoeken.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: Studenten zijn na dit vak in staat een gefundeerde keuze te maken uit dataverzameling en analysemethoden, voor exploratief, beschrijvend, verklarend en toetsend onderzoek. Daartoe hebben zij naast de kennis uit Inleiding methoden en technieken nu ook inzicht in de basiskenmerken en principes van kwalitatieve dataverzamelingsmethoden als intevriewen en observeren en van belangrijke bestaande kwantitatieve databronnen. Studenten kunnen bovendien de gegevens die voortkomen uit kwalitatief onderzoek thematisch coderen en analyseren en weten welke ethische problemen er kleven aan kwalitatief onderzoek. Tot slot kunnen zij hun reflecties en bevindingen presenteren in een wetenschappelijk artikel.

Wat betreft kwantitatieve analysemethoden kunnen zij bivariate en multivariate analyses uitvoeren met variabelen van verschillende meetniveaus en de uitkomsten daarvan interpreteren en daarover rapporteren. Ook zijn studenten in staat methoden en resultatenbeschrijvingen in wetenschappelijke literatuur te begrijpen en kritisch na te gaan of de uitspraken die worden gedaan terecht zijn, gegeven de gebruikte onderzoeksmethoden.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92587,2020,Methoden van Forensisch Handelen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. FCP van der Horst', 'MKM Lunnemann, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In dit practicum gaan de studenten actief aan de slag met de praktische uitwerking van wat in het algemeen wordt gezien als de basis voor het handelen in het forensisch werkveld, namelijk het risicobeginsel, het behoeftebeginsel en het responsiviteitsbeginsel. Studenten leren (1) op basis van gevalideerde instrumenten het recidiverisico in te schatten, (2) hoe in behandeling te interveniëren op criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van een cliënt en (3) hoe om te gaan met niet-gemotiveerde cliënten en hoe motiverende gespreksvoering toe te passen in de forensische praktijk.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afronding van dit practicum hebben studenten:

column2: • kennis van de in het forensisch werkveld veelgebruikte What works?-principes uit het Risk-Needs-Responsivity model (Bonta & Andrews, 2007; Ward & Stewart, 2003) en daarmee van de uitgangspunten voor effectieve diagnostiek en behandeling in een forensisch kader;;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• kennisgemaakt met de rol van risicotaxatie in het forensisch veld;
• zicht op de behandeling van criminogene en niet-criminogene behoeften van cliënten en kennen zij het onderscheid tussen statische en dynamische risicofactoren;
• zich bewust van algemene werkzaamheid van interventies en de noodzaak in behandeling rekening te houden met specifieke eigenschappen van de cliënt in zijn specifieke context;;
• basisvaardigheden van motiverende gespreksvoering (Miller & Rollnick, 2012) onder de knie.

column1: De student is in staat om zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):

column2: • Een samenhangende en heldere rapportage te schrijven;
• Een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen en deze af te stemmen op een specifieke doelgroep (e.g. kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten en andere professionals);
• Een casusbeschrijving conform NVO-richtlijnen betreffende de BAPD te schrijven.

column1: This course deepens the methodological expertise that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. While the course covers the basic features and applicability of various research methods, the emphasis is on students’ own usage of these methods, specifically at the design and data gathering stages of the research process. The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently and strengths the skills needed in the research workshops and the MA thesis, which follow later in the program. Key research methods in the field are covered in the course, including surveys, in-depth interviews, qualitative content analysis and quantitative content analysis. The various methods are taught by different lecturers who bring their own research expertise to the modules. Thus, each of the four methods is discussed over a period of two weeks and concluded with an assignment where students develop an adequate research design and engage in limited data collection. Thematically, the research designs developed for the assignments in this course cover topics such as popular culture and political communication, or social media.

column2: <title></title>

column1: Studenten hebben kennis van en inzicht  in:

column2: • Gangbare onderzoeksmethoden op het gebied van media en communicatie.
• De voornaamste verschillen in de manier waarop specifieke onderzoeksmethoden worden gebruikt en het soort data dat ze genereren.
• Onderzoek op te zetten en  meetinstrumenten en sampling strategieën (met betrekking tot specifieke  methoden) te evalueren.
• Hun eigen onderzoeksopzet, meetinstrumenten en sampling strategieën ten aanzien van concrete onderzoeksvragen  over media-inhoud of mediagebruik te ontwikkelen.
• Bruikbare data te verzamelen.
• Op hun gebruik van verschillende onderzoeksmethoden te reflecteren.
• Met collega’s onderzoeksstrategieën te bediscussiëren, te ontwikkelen en te beoordelen.

De seminars bestaan deels uit het overdragen van kennis over de specifieke methodologische thematiek van dat seminar, en een gedeelte is gericht op het oefenen en ontwikkelen van de bijbehorende vaardigheden.</body>

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The course will introduce students to key concepts and arguments surrounding:

A) Theoretical modelling: explanation, understanding, idealization and abstraction, causal tendencies, modal hypotheses, the distinction between the practice of theoretical model building and applied models.

B) Causal inference: the Causal Markov assumption, exogeneity, heterogeneity, choosing an appropriate set of control variables, background causal knowledge, Bayesian methods, and hypothetico-deductive approaches in economics, especially Friedman’s instrumentalism.
C) Econometrics: the Lucas critique / microfoundations debates, structural models, the assumptions of regression analyses, representative agent models, methodological individualism

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: By the end of this course, students can:

1) Clarify the aims of idealized modelling in economics, and critically assess whether these models meet these aims, drawing on the debate between Cartwright, Alexandrova, Sugden, Reiss, Maki, Hausman and Till Grune Yanoff.
2) Examine the extent to which economics is value-laden, and evaluate whether this is desirable or undesirable

3) Explain and distinguish the main obstacles to causal inference in economics, both for observational studies using regression analysis or instrumental variables techniques, or for social experiments.

4) Relate these general obstacles to causal inferences in economics to particular issues arising in econometrics, including the debate over microfoundations for macroeconomic models, influential critiques of macroeconomics by Leamer and Roemer.

column1: This course deepens the methodological expertise that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently and strengths the skills needed in the research workshops and the MA thesis, which follow later in the program. Key research methods in the field are covered in the course, including surveys, in-depth interviews, experiments, and qualitative content analysis. The various methods are taught by different lecturers who bring their own research expertise to the modules. column1: This course deepens the data analysis expertise which students have gained in prior studies and preparatory trainings. The focus is on some of the most commonly used methods of data analysis in the social sciences, in general, and the field of media and communication, in particular. Half of the course will therefore focus on quantitative methods of data-analysis (such as T-tests, Anova, factor, and regression analysis), while the other half will focus on qualitative methods (such as thematic analysis, discourse analysis and visual analysis). Questions regarding validity and reliability of research will be addressed as well. In the weekly seminars, time will be spent on practicing methods, while the weekly lectures will cover the methodological steps more in-depth and from a theoretical perspective. Students will apply some of the methods they practiced with during the course to complete a qualitative- and a quantitative-methods assignment.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• common methods of both quantitative and qualitative data analysis in media and communication;
• strengths and weaknesses of each discussed method of analysis.
• choose these covered method of analysis that best fits their research design;
• apply the covered methods when analyzing media content, processes, uses, and influences;
• report their analyses in oral and written form.

column2: <title></title>
