<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In onderzoek, maar zeker ook in de praktijk en in beleidsvorming, staat de rol van de moeder in de opvoeding en ontwikkeling van kinderen centraal. Echter, er is geen kind dat enkel door een moeder wordt opgevoed. Ondanks dat moeders veelal de primaire verzorger zijn, doet de eenzijdige aandacht voor de rol van de moeder onrecht aan de rol van andere opvoeders binnen en buiten het gezin. Binnen dit blok nemen we de rol van vader binnen opvoeding en ontwikkeling van het kind onder de loep. Welke positie neemt vader in naast de moeder en leveren vaders een unieke bijdrage aan de opvoeding en ontwikkeling? Hoe kunnen we als professionals rekening houden met het gezinssysteem? In de afgelopen decennia is er veel veranderd in taakverdeling binnen gezinnen. Vaders zijn, deels door de toenemende arbeidsparticipatie van vrouwen, in hogere mate betrokken bij opvoeding en verzorging van kinderen, tot aan “papadagen” aan toe. Ontwikkelen kinderen zich daardoor anders? Wat is de invloed van twee werkende ouders op kinderen? Welke rol speelt kinderopvang hierin? In dit blok worden theorie, onderzoek en de dagelijkse praktijk van opvoeders binnen en buiten het gezin geëvalueerd. Binnen het blok wordt de link gelegd tussen empirie en de huidige praktijk door aan casussen te werken die de alledaagse opvoedvragen blootleggen. De nauwe link met het practicum (Ontwerpen van een preventie-/interventieprogramma) zorgt voor praktische handvatten om als toekomstig professional de link tussen wetenschap en praktijk te maken.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • De verschillende constructen binnen het thema ‘Opvoeden binnen en buiten het gezin’ te operationaliseren en toe te lichten vanuit verschillende theoretische perspectieven;
• De geschiedenis en huidige inzichten binnen het thema ‘Opvoeden binnen en buiten het gezin’ te evalueren;
• De effecten van de verschillende vormen van opvoeding binnen en buiten het gezin op het kind en het gezinssysteem te analyseren en evalueren;
• Kritisch te reflecteren op instrumenten die worden gebruikt in onderzoek naar opvoeders binnen en buiten het gezin.

column3: De primaire taak van orthopedagogen is opvoeders te ondersteunen in de opvoeding van hun kinderen zodanig dat kinderen zich optimaal kunnen ontwikkelen en ontplooien. Wanneer kinderen een beperking hebben bijv. qua lichamelijk of verstandelijk functioneren kan dit leiden tot een verzwaarde opvoedingsopgave en rust er een zware verantwoordelijkheid op de schouders van de orthopedagoog om opvoeders (ouders, leerkrachten, groepsleiders) op wetenschappelijk onderbouwde en cultureel gepaste wijze zal ondersteunen in hun opvoedingstaken. Dit is tot nu toe besproken in blok 1.6 en 2.6. Echter, problemen staan meestal niet op zichzelf. Het is al zwaar voor ouders om een kind op te voeden met een specifieke opvoedingsproblematiek, maar vaak zijn er binnen een gezin ook nog andere problemen. Een kind met ODD in een huishouden waarvan een van de ouders afwezig is, er financiële problemen zijn en er meer kinderen aanwezig zijn die aandacht behoeven, wordt de opvoeding van een kind met deze problematiek nog zwaarder. Daarnaast kunnen taalbarrières, verschil in culturele achtergrond en daarmee ook verschil in pedagogische opvattingen nog voor extra problemen zorgen. Dit is echter wel de complexe werkelijkheid, zeker binnen grootstedelijke cultuur. Verschillende combinaties van orthopedagogische thema's worden in de problemen van het blok uitgediept waarbij het wetenschappelijk verantwoord en – onderbouwd handelen van de professionele orthopedagoog centraal staat.</body>

column1: De inhoud van het vak organisatie en strategie is onderverdeeld in drie blokken: de onderneming, de markt, en de [macro-]omgeving.

Naast een theoretische verklaring van de begrippen wordt er veel aandacht besteed aan het uitleggen en de relevantie van de behandelde begrippen door middel van uitgebreide praktijkvoorbeelden. Dit gebeurt zowel in de hoorcolleges, de gastcolleges, de practica als tijdens de vaardigheden bijeenkomsten.
De volgende onderwerpen komen aan de orde:

column2: • De horizontale en verticale grenzen van de onderneming.
• Agency en coordinatie.
• Alternatieven voor maak-of-koop beslissingen.
• Diversificatie.
• Concurrenten en concurrentie.
• Strategische committering en prijsrivaliteit.
• Toetreding en uittreding.
• Strategische positionering en concurrentievoordeel.
• Innovatie.
• De macro-omgeving van de onderneming.

column1: In this course, students are introduced to various organization theories and management approaches that provide insight into organisations operating in the public sector. Organization theories provide mechanisms that explain how organizations are configured, and why individuals in organizational settings operate and behave in the way they do.

Students for example learn in this course to identify mechanisms that explain how incentives affect organisational activities, the role of organisational boundaries, and how structures, culture, and institutions affects behaviour in organisations.

The management approaches provide insight into the role of management and managers in public sector organisations. In the course, students learn for example about managerial activities related to functional areas of management (HRM, ICT-management, strategy formation, financial management, et cetera) as well as about the conditions and leadership skills that are needed in order to manage organisations and implement organisational change.

column1: <body>After having followed the course, students are able to

column2: • explain how organizations (as ‘whole entities’) operate in an environment that consists of market-like mechanisms, political structures, and networks;
• define central concepts within organizations, such as coordination and adaptation mechanisms, organizational structures, and organizational cultures, and explain how these concepts are related;
• define various managerial activities and explain their role in organizations;
• identify causes and conditions of organizational change; and
• explain the role that management plays in organizational change.

column1: In this course we introduce participants to the process of organizational development and change, with a particular focus on the role of HR Management in interaction with line management and consultants as professional facilitators of these processes. The course involves six interactive lecture/workshops with discussions of the required readings, presentation of team-assignments, cases and exercises. Individual and team preparation for the meetings is required through preparatory assignments. The course aims to enhance participants' insight in processes of organizational change and development, and examines both formal and informal aspects of organizational functioning. In the weekly meetings, required readings are discussed and student teams present short assignments directly related to the topic of the specific meeting, aimed at understanding and gaining personal ownership of the presented insights. Examples of topics are: experiencing change, developing organizations, the role of the change agent, power and politics, resistance to change, change dynamics, institutional change, organizational learning, management and employee attitudes, strategies for change and change design. We study these phenomena and investigate the possible change management roles for HRM and other actors in the process of change (diagnosing the situation, recognizing development tendencies, designing and facilitating effective and responsible processes of development and change).</body>

3.    Have experienced some basic consulting skills (critical diagnosis and analysis, organizing and facilitating of a session, presentation skills)
4.    Have improved their ability to work in a team
5.    Have developed an understanding of the responsibility inherent in change management
6.    Have furthered their insight in their own preferences, attitudes, strength and weaknesses in dealing with change issues</body>

column1: The contents of the course organisation and strategy cover three blocks: the firm, the market, and the [macro-]environment.

Besides a theoretical approach to these concepts, considerable attention is directed to the explanation and relevance of the concepts by means of extensive practical examples and applications. These examples are discussed during the plenary lectures, guest lectures, working groups, as well as the skills classes.
During the course the following topics are discussed:

column2: • The horizontal and vertical boundaries of the firm.
• Agency and coordination
• Alternatives for make-or-buy decisions
• Diversification
• Competitors and competition
• Strategic commitment and pricing rivalry
• Entry and exit
• Strategic positioning and competitive advantage
• Innovation
• The macro-environment of the firm

• To identify and analyse the strategic reactions of firms to changes in the external environment.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/94747,2020,Organisation of Innovation,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. HJD Klapper', 'dr. S Tasselli', 'dr. TH van Balen, MPhil']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Generation, recognition, adoption and sharing of innovation is certainly a challenge for every organization, but creating an organizational structure that enables an organization to continuously innovate is also an equally, or even more, daunting task. This course will introduce the central challenges and available solutions to organize innovation activities.

Central topics encompass the processes by which innovation is generated, idea generation, theories of organization of innovation, organizing in service organizations, innovation networks, and organizational design in start-ups also through prototypes. The theoretical knowledge will be supported with case studies, skill development activities and guest speakers with whom the student will have the unique opportunity to discuss and share their opinion.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The course ‘Organisation of Innovation’ focuses on the management and organisation of the innovation process at large and small enterprises from a global perspective, as well on the organizational conditions that either facilitate or hamper the generations and transfer of innovation. There are two central questions:  how this process has to be organised to be able to deliver high quality products and services with short time-to-market in an efficient way. And how innovation can be managed such that it can be easily transferred across boundaries (e.g., among individuals, networks and and organizational units) Contradicting tensions have to be managed, such as creativity, coordination and flexibility versus learning, formal organization and efficiency. The course will equip students with general knowledge of the topic and skills such as organizational design overcoming interpersonal and organizational resistance.</body>

column1: Organisational Behaviour BT1202 is an introduction to the study of human behaviour in organisations. These behaviours are mainly explained in reference to psychological mechanisms, situational factors, individual differences, and group phenomena that influence the way people interact. As such, Organisational Behaviour is an applied science that builds on contributions from a number of different disciplines, particularly psychology, social psychology, sociology, and anthropology. The course will especially emphasize the psychological and social psychological factors that influence behaviour in organisations.

During the course, you will be assigned readings that discuss what people do in organisations and how their behaviour affects the organisation’s performance. You will then have the opportunity to consider how this research in Organisational Behaviour is or could be applied to improve organisational effectiveness.

Some of the specific topics that we will cover in this class are: personality, attitudes and job satisfaction, social perceptions and decision making, stereotyping and prejudice, motivation, leader behaviour, group structure and processes, social influence and social interaction, diversity, as well as emotions and mood. This class will also provide a solid foundation for courses you will encounter later in the curriculum, namely “Organisational Theory and Dynamics” and “Human Resource Management”.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Understand basic facts, research findings, terminology, principles, theories, and controversies important to organisational behaviour;
• Describe the foundations of individual behaviour and how these relate to work behaviour;
• Collaboratively apply basic organisational behaviour knowledge to real cases;
• Demonstrate a critical mindset of recognizing and acknowledging one’s own and others’ limitations with regards to human behaviour at organisations and become sensitive for individual differences.

column1: <body>Employees are of crucial importance for the delivery of health care and the performance of health care organisations. Therefore, the management of health care organisations involves managing people. This course aims to provide insights in the behaviour of individuals and groups in organisations and the effects on performance and health care delivery. The first part of the course focusses on the management of employees using insights from Human Resource Management and leadership theories. Further, dilemmas and tensions related to leadership, performance management, teamwork, patient-centeredness, professionals, and well-being within healthcare organizations will be discussed. The following topics are covered in this course:

column2: • HRM: what is it and does it matter?
• Performance: what is measured and what are the consequences for professionals?
• Leadership: the impact on performance, what influences the effectiveness of leadership?
• Teams: why teamwork and what are the tensions/dilemmas related to teams?
• Professionals: effects of health care trends and management on professionalsLanguage: Lectures are in English

<body>

column3: Sinds het begin van de 20ste eeuw zijn psychologen met een kritische blik ‘het organiseren van werk’ gaan bestuderen. Wat is eigenlijk een organisatie? Werknemer Jan vindt dat zijn organisatie op een gevangenis lijkt, werknemer Piet vindt zijn bedrijf net een politieke partij. Deze verschillen in perceptie hebben met diverse `harde` en `zachte` factoren te maken. Denk maar aan (in volgorde van hard naar zacht) de hiërarchische relaties of formele machtsverhoudingen tussen medewerkers, de werkvormen, de wijze waarop medewerkers met elkaar communiceren, het geheel van ongeschreven normen en waarden, en informele machtsverhoudingen die er heersen.

Een belangrijke  vraag in organisatiepsychologie is hoe je een goede diagnose van een organisatie uitvoert. Daarom, zullen we ook aandacht besteden aan kwalitatieve methodes (zoals de casestudy methodiek) en kwantitatieve methodes (zoals het gebruik vragenlijsten voor het meten van organisatiecultuur).

Organisaties zijn geen losstaande entiteiten: ze evolueren onder invloed van economische, technologische en maatschappelijke impulsen. Denk maar aan het fuseren of het afslanken van bedrijven, de invloed van ontwikkelingen binnen de informatietechnologie, etc.
Organisatieverandering, –innovatie en de invloed op de diagnose en adviesverlening zijn eveneens belangrijk thema’s die organisatiepsychologen bestuderen.

Tot slot, het bestuderen van organisaties is een interdisciplinaire aangelegenheid: niet alleen psychologen maar ook sociologen, economen, bedrijfsdeskundigen en zelfs antropologen zijn actief op dit terrein. Zo zullen we thema’s bestuderen die nauw aansluiten bij de organisatiekunde zoals theorieën over organiseren, organisatievormen en -denkbeelden (denk aan de percepties van Jan en Piet!). Toch richten we ons hoofdzakelijk op datgene wat de psycholoog over de arbeidsorganisatie te vertellen heeft.

Alles bij elkaar, zullen we aandacht besteden aan het macroniveau van organisaties (organisatiestructuur, -strategie, -cultuur, -verandering en -innovatie) en het microniveau van organisaties (werknemerspercepties van oneerlijkheid, destructieve en constructieve werkgedrag, creativiteit enz.)

column1: The course Organisational Theory and Dynamics builds on prior courses such as Organisational Behavior and HRM. The course covers two themes as already indicated in the title. The first theme is about analysing and diagnosing the social structure and its design elements in an organisation. New forms of organising will be elaborated as well. This is the core of organisation theory.

In the second theme we will focus on a more dynamic perspective of an organisation. This theme will cover the broad topic of organisational change. More specific topics are type of change mechanisms and contextual influences on change such as culture and politics.

As concepts in organisation theory and dynamics are easy to understand but require careful thoughts when used to evaluate a complex organisational situation, this course requires both studying the main theoretical concepts based on a custom-made book and also applying them. For this last aim, the pre-recorded lectures will be complemented with an interactive Q & A session complemented with quizzes. Also the case ‘Housing Anywhere’ will be discussed – this case is about the design of an organization, internal alignment and coordination processes during a process of internationalization and growth – the other case called ""Strategic Changes at Royal IHC: Causes, Effects, Reactions and Possible Solutions"" is covering a real-life change project as it was happening until 2020. This case is offered in an interactive form and makes up for the team assignment.

The goal of the interactive sessions and the team assignment is, first, to stimulate making a link between theory and practice on an analytical level and, second, to use theoretical concepts for developing recommendations based on a request originating in practice. In the pre-recorded lectures core concepts from both fields are introduced and put in their current context. The lectures together with the textbook provide building blocks for the interactive sessions and the case assignment and ultimately for the written test.

Material relevant for the interactive sessions on Zoom about social structure and especially about integration mechanisms will be posted on Canvas in due time. We will together discuss and answer quizzes related to the posted material, especially the case ‘Housing Anywhere’.

The case ""Strategic Changes at Royal IHC: Causes, Effects, Reactions and Possible Solutions"" is designed as a team assignment in an interactive way. A team of students has to answer questions within Qualtrics or critically discuss an event during the change project at IHC. This case is designed in such a way that various angles (e.g. top management, employees etc.) regarding the change processes provide their view on how the change was going. You will work on this case as a team.

column1: <body>This course examines the topic of organized crime and aims for students to develop a critical understanding of its conceptualization, social organization and the social reaction to it. Based on different cases of organized crime (for instance drugs smuggling, waste dumping, money laundering, outlaw motorcycle gangs, wildlife smuggling) students will analyze the definition, historical and contemporary causes, and local and supranational responses to organized crime.

This is a social science course, not a legal course, but basic understanding of legal concepts is assumed and necessary. For example, we expect students to understand the difference between criminal and administrative law and to have a basic understanding of the different type of organizations in their country that are involved in regulating, supervising, and enforcing crime.

Knowledge of criminological theory is not directly assessed in this course but is implicitly taken as prior knowledge. For those students who do not have a background in criminology or criminal justice and therefore have a limited knowledge of criminological theory, the following books are useful:
•       Carrabine, E. et al. (2014). Criminology: A sociological introduction. 3rd edition. London: Routledge, chapters 1; 5; 7; 13; 20; 23.
•       Newburn, T. (2016). Criminology. London: Routledge, chapters 1; 5; 14; 18; 22.

This course uses a case-based design. In case-based learning, students work in groups on contemporary real-life cases of organised crime. Students prepare for class in small groups answering preparation questions about their own case and the prescribed literature. Classes consist of lively interactive discussions amongst students integrating knowledge from the literature and the different cases. The lecturers facilitate discussion and provide feedback on key take-aways from each session. Regular guest lectures also help spark further discussion about contemporary topics of organized crime. The grade in this course is a composite of in class participation, individual knowledge quizzes and a written assignment. Students are expected to contribute substantially to in-class discussion as well as to group work. Course attendance is compulsory.

A first aim of this course is to provide students with a critical understanding of organized crime within its historical and contemporary context. We will discuss the characteristics, harms and scale of different types of organized crime (for instance drugs smuggling, waste dumping, money laundering, outlaw motorcycle gangs, wildlife smuggling). This also ties into an analysis of how the scientific and policy debate about organized crime has evolved over time. Second, students will analyze the social organization of organized crime. This relates to questions about motives and opportunities for different types of organized crime. This addresses questions of social and structural embeddedness, violence, secrecy, trust and corruption, types of actors involved and interfaces between legal and illegal actors. This brings together different theoretical perspectives and empirical studies on organized crime. Third, students will assess the strengths and weaknesses of various national and supranational prevention and control policies and law enforcement strategies. This will address how policy has developed historically, discussing the influence of the US, and contrasting this with the policy approaches of the European Union and the Netherlands. We discuss criminal investigations into organized crime with global and local relevance as well as address what other means are available to counter it. This aims to provide students with the necessary building blocks to develop policy advice on effective enforcement strategies.
Upon completion of the course, the student should be able:

column2: • To examine the characteristics, harms and scale of organized crime;
• To critically appraise empirical research on organized crime.
• To deconstruct and compare different theories about the social organized of organized crime;
• To evaluate which explanations apply to specific cases of organized crime;
• To examine the implications for policy making of organized crime cases;
• To critically appraise the prevention and control policies for organized crime on the national and international level;
• To formulate policy advice on effective enforcement strategies.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: <body>This course examines the topic of organized crime and aims for students to develop a critical understanding of its conceptualization, social organization and the social reaction to it. Based on different cases of organized crime (for instance drugs smuggling, waste dumping, money laundering, outlaw motorcycle gangs, wildlife smuggling) students will analyze the definition, historical and contemporary causes, and local and supranational responses to organized crime.

This is a social science course, not a legal course, but basic understanding of legal concepts is assumed and necessary. For example, we expect students to understand the difference between criminal and administrative law and to have a basic understanding of the different type of organizations in their country that are involved in regulating, supervising, and enforcing crime.

Knowledge of criminological theory is not directly assessed in this course but is implicitly taken as prior knowledge. For those students who do not have a background in criminology or criminal justice and therefore have a limited knowledge of criminological theory, the following books are useful:
•       Carrabine, E. et al. (2014). Criminology: A sociological introduction. 3rd edition. London: Routledge, chapters 1; 5; 7; 13; 20; 23.
•       Newburn, T. (2016). Criminology. London: Routledge, chapters 1; 5; 14; 18; 22.

This course uses a case-based design. In case-based learning, students work in groups on contemporary real-life cases of organised crime. Students prepare for class in small groups answering preparation questions about their own case and the prescribed literature. Classes consist of lively interactive discussions amongst students integrating knowledge from the literature and the different cases. The lecturers facilitate discussion and provide feedback on key take-aways from each session. Regular guest lectures also help spark further discussion about contemporary topics of organized crime. The grade in this course is a composite of in class participation, individual knowledge quizzes and a written assignment. Students are expected to contribute substantially to in-class discussion as well as to group work. Course attendance is compulsory.

A first aim of this course is to provide students with a critical understanding of organized crime within its historical and contemporary context. We will discuss the characteristics, harms and scale of different types of organized crime (for instance drugs smuggling, waste dumping, money laundering, outlaw motorcycle gangs, wildlife smuggling). This also ties into an analysis of how the scientific and policy debate about organized crime has evolved over time. Second, students will analyze the social organization of organized crime. This relates to questions about motives and opportunities for different types of organized crime. This addresses questions of social and structural embeddedness, violence, secrecy, trust and corruption, types of actors involved and interfaces between legal and illegal actors. This brings together different theoretical perspectives and empirical studies on organized crime. Third, students will assess the strengths and weaknesses of various national and supranational prevention and control policies and law enforcement strategies. This will address how policy has developed historically, discussing the influence of the US, and contrasting this with the policy approaches of the European Union and the Netherlands. We discuss criminal investigations into organized crime with global and local relevance as well as address what other means are available to counter it. This aims to provide students with the necessary building blocks to develop policy advice on effective enforcement strategies.
Upon completion of the course, the student should be able:

column2: • To examine the characteristics, harms and scale of organized crime;
• To critically appraise empirical research on organized crime.
• To deconstruct and compare different theories about the social organized of organized crime;
• To evaluate which explanations apply to specific cases of organized crime;
• To examine the implications for policy making of organized crime cases;
• To critically appraise the prevention and control policies for organized crime on the national and international level;
• To formulate policy advice on effective enforcement strategies.

column4: <div>

column5: In dit blok geven we een introductie in de Arbeids- en Organisatiepsychologie. De meeste volwassen mensen brengen een aanzienlijk deel van hun tijd door op hun werk. Aan de centrale plek van werk in het leven dankt de A&O-psycholoog zijn bestaan. Met haar 100-jarige bestaan is de A&O-psychologie een jonge discipline binnen de psychologie. In die 100 jaar hebben we veel geleerd. Honderd jaar geleden nog dachten we dat arbeiders lui waren en met harde hand in het gareel gehouden moesten worden. Onze vroege vakgenoten hielden zich bijvoorbeeld bezig met het ontleden van taken om nauwkeurig te kunnen zeggen hoe en in welk tempo arbeiders handelingen moesten uitvoeren. Dit waren de hoogtijdagen van de lopende band. Pas later realiseerde men zich hoe frustrerend deze manier van werken kon zijn. Er kwam aandacht voor "intrinsieke motivatie", afwisselend werk en sociale relaties. De moderne A&O-psycholoog besteedt veel aandacht aan thema’s als werving en selectie, samenwerken, zelfontplooiing, plezier in het werk en arbeid en gezondheid.

column4: In Blok 2.8 bestuderen we menselijke prestaties op de werkplek. In het bijzonder onderzoeken we wat prestatie is, hoe het ingeschat, geëvalueerd en ontwikkeld wordt gedurende de professionele loopbaan.

De volgende thema’s komen aan bod: (1) wat verstaan we onder werkprestaties? Hoe kunnen we prestaties en potentieel beoordelen en wat zijn de valkuilen (performance Appraisal)? (2 & 3) Wat zijn goede voorspellers voor prestatie? (4) Wat zijn belangrijke kenmerken waaraan training moet voldoen, hoe kun je mensen het beste iets leren? (5) Hoe kunnen we prestaties op de werkplek verbeteren en behouden (beloning). (6) Welke fundamentele biologische of evolutionaire processen kunnen een rol spelen bij prestatie en prestatiebeoordeling. (7) Hoe verlopen loopbanen (carrières) en hoe kan men werknemers begeleiden tijdens loopbanen (loopbaantheorieën, loopbaancounseling) (8) Hoe zit het met geslachtsverschillen op de werkvloer. Dit laatste onderwerp is een soort overkoepelend thema waarin alle andere thema’s naar voren kunnen komen (loopbanen, prestatie, beloning, etc.).

De bovengenoemde thema’s hebben allemaal betrekking op aspecten van Human Resource Management (HRM). Je zult echter merken dat de thema’s zeker ook voor toekomstige onderwijs-, klinische, biologisch/cognitieve en arbeidspsychologen relevant zijn.

column1: Technological change (e.g., the emergence of new digital technologies such as Artificial Intelligence and Internet of Things) leads to major organizational challenges for many firms. In recent years, the investments in industrial research and development (R&D) have increased in many sectors. To provide a beneficial organizational context for the exploration, assimilation, retention, and exploitation of new technological knowledge, firms need to consider specific organizational and management concepts, which are addressed in detail in this course.

The students gain detailed knowledge about fundamental issues concerning strategies, organizational capabilities and organizational designs with respect to technological change. Among other aspects, the course addresses organizational issues related to technology forecasting, knowledge governance, R&D processes and structures, absorption of new external knowledge, strategic technology alliances, technology-based M&A activities, as well as leadership and HR management in R&D.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: •    Understanding why and how some companies survive technological changes, and others do not.
•    Analyzing various organizational and management dimensions of technological transformation in businesses.

•    Acquiring and applying relevant concepts and tools related to the exploration, retention, and exploitation of new technological knowledge to solve real company case problems associated with strategic challenges.
•    Evaluating the effects of different organizational design elements on companies’ technological transformations.
•    Recommending strategies for companies to take advantage of technological disruptions on the basis of relevant concepts and case studies and reflecting critically on own conclusions.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/92678,2020,Orthopedagogiek: Stoornissen bij kinderen,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. NK Schoemaker', 'ES Kruit, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Blok 2.7 is het logisch vervolg op blok 1.6 Orthopedagogiek I. In Blok 1.6 heb je kennis gemaakt met de discipline van de Orthopedagogiek als oorspronkelijk handelingswetenschap en tegenwoordig steeds meer als empirische wetenschap. Daarnaast ben je bekend met de grondleggers en werkvelden van de orthopedagogische praktijk en het gebruik van de diverse cycli bij theorievorming, diagnostiek en hulpverlening door orthopedagogen. Blok 2.7 is een verbreding en verdieping van orthopedagogische kennis en handelen met als centraal thema stoornissen bij jeugdigen.

De primaire taak van orthopedagogen is opvoeders te ondersteunen in de opvoeding van hun kinderen zodanig dat kinderen zich optimaal kunnen ontwikkelen en ontplooien. Wanneer kinderen een ontwikkelings- of andere stoornis hebben, kan dit leiden tot een verzwaarde opvoedingsopgave of -last en rust er een zware verantwoordelijkheid op de schouders van de orthopedagoog om opvoeders (ouders, andere gezins- en familieleden, maar ook groepsleiders en leerkrachten) op wetenschappelijk onderbouwde en cultureel gepaste wijze te ondersteunen in hun opvoedingstaken.

In dit blok worden de meest voorkomende gedragsproblemen, ontwikkelingsstoornissen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen behandeld aan de hand van prevalentie, vermeende oorzaken vanuit diverse wetenschappelijke perspectieven, co-morbiditeit, prognose, (de geschiedenis van) diagnostiek en meest belangrijke of populaire vormen van behandeling of ondersteuning met betrekking tot deze problemen en stoornissen.

Kinderen met internaliserende en externaliserende gedragsproblemen (zoals angst, depressie, Conduct Disorder/ODD) en ontwikkelingsstoornissen (zoals Autisme Spectrum stoornissen, ADHD), persoonlijkheidsstoornissen (zoals borderline persoonlijkheidsstoornis) en leerproblemen (dyscalculie, dyslexie) staan centraal in dit blok. De focus ligt op het orthopedagogisch handelen. Er zal dus worden bekeken hoe zo’n probleem is ontstaan, wat dit betekent voor het kind, voor de ouders en voor de directe leefomgeving van het kind en hoe, vanuit een orthopedagogisch perspectief, het kind, zijn/haar gezin en de bredere sociale omgeving ondersteund kunnen worden.

Naast de blokken 2.6 en 2.8 maak je in dit blok kennis met de vraagstukken waar pedagogen en onderwijswetenschappers in de beroepspraktijk voor staan en welke instrumenten en interventies daar veelal bij gebruikt worden.

column1: Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • een beschrijving te geven van kenmerken, prevalentie, prognose, co-morbiditeit van ontwikkelingsstoornissen, (internaliserende en externaliserende) gedragsproblemen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen en deze stoornissen/problemen onderling te vergelijken (eindtermen 3 en 5);

• de meeste belangrijke wetenschappelijke theorieën en verklaringen vanuit diverse perspectieven voor deze ontwikkelingsstoornissen, (internaliserende en externaliserende) gedragsproblemen, persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en leerproblemen te beschrijven en de daarmee verband houdende wetenschappelijke onderzoeken te beschrijven en deze theorieën en verklaringen over stoornissen/problemen heen te vergelijken (eindtermen 4 en 6);

• het proces van diagnostiek en hulpverlening aan de hand van de klinische cyclus te beschrijven en de bijbehorende theoretische modellen te kennen voor de eerder genoemde problematiek, waarbij oog is voor overeenkomsten en verschillen over problematieken heen (eindterm 5);

• voorgenoemde wetenschappelijke theorieën en verklaringen, onderzoeken en orthopedagogische toepassingen te evalueren op sterke en minder sterke (of ronduit zwakke) punten en –op basis hiervan- het geëvalueerde op wetenschappelijke, praktische waarde te beoordelen (eindtermen 6, 11 en 14).

column1: De klassieke Oudheid vormt het begin van de Westerse wijsbegeerte; met name de Griekse Oudheid kenmerkt zich door een verbazingwekkende rijkheid aan filosofen en denkbeelden, die ons denken tot op de dag van vandaag op diepgaande wijze hebben beïnvloed. De cursus begint met de eerste Griekse filosofen, nog voor Socrates, en vervolgens zullen diens leven en ideeën worden behandeld binnen de contekst van het Athene van de vijfde eeuw voor Christus. Vervolgens komt de metafysische en de kentheoretische invulling aan bod die Plato gaf aan de erfenis van Socrates, waarna de filosofie van diens leerling Aristoteles wordt behandeld. Daarbij zal aandacht worden besteed aan diens metafysica, kenleer, logica, ethiek en (mogelijk ook) zijn politieke filosofie. De periode vanaf Aristoteles kenmerkt zich door de dramatische historische veranderingen die in gang worden gezet door zijn beroemdste leerling, namelijk Alexander de Grote. Door diens veroveringen breidt de Griekse wereld zich uit over het gehele oostelijke gedeelte van de Middellandse Zee en ver daarbuiten. In de Hellenistische periode daarna ontwikkelen zich de Stoïsche en Epicureïsche scholen, die zich concentreren op logica, een materialistische fysica en vooral een ethiek waarin de afwezigheid van leed als het hoogste goed wordt verdedigd. De cursus wordt afgesloten met het syncretische gedachtengoed van de neoplatonist Plotinus.
De werkcolleges zijn verplicht voor voltijdstudenten.

column1: In het vak Overheid en Markt wordt aandacht besteed aan de complexe relatie tussen markt en overheid in de context van marktregulering en het borgen van economische en niet-economische publieke belangen en de impact van het Europeesrechtelijk kader daarop.

De vraag is welke combinatie van markt en overheid zorgt voor een goede behartiging van de vele belangen van de samenleving. Hoe stellen we die publieke belangen vast? Welke belangen primeren? Wat is de ratio achter verschillende vormen van regulering? Welke rol speelt het Europees economisch recht in dat verband? En hoe is het gesteld met de rechtsbescherming wanneer een onderneming te maken krijgt met marktregulering of een concrete overheidsinterventie?

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Pain is an all-too-familiar problem and the most common reason that people see a physician. Pain is an adaptive process and serves an important purpose by alerting us to potential tissue damage and injuries and thereby inducing protective reactions. For a long time, pain was considered as a purely physical sensation and symptom of an underlying somatic disease. In the last decades, it has become clearer and clearer that pain is a psycho-biological experience including sensory and emotional components.

In this course, students will be introduced to the biological and psychological underpinnings of pain and experimental paradigms to investigate pain in the psychological laboratory. The main focus will be on psychological factors of pain such as the influence of emotions, attention, expectations (placebo-effect). Other topics of this course include phenomena such as phantom limb pain or chronification of pain and their underlying neurocognitive mechanisms. Furthermore, diagnostics of pain and different psychological treatment approaches will be discussed.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The aim of this course is to increase students' knowledge of a topic, which has gained increased interest in Clinical Psychology in recent years: Pain and its modulation by psychological factors. The main goal is for students to learn about recent scientific insights into the neurobiological basis and psychological models of pain, its modulation by psychological factors, and (psychological) treatment methods.

column1: Nowadays, even mobile phones and tablets have multiple core central processing units (CPUs), as do have the simplest laptop and desktop PCs. Using their combined compute power, however, is not trivial. This is as true for the small systems, as well as (worlds) largest computer systems. In data science, making use efficiently of all compute power is a required skill that needs to be learned. In this course you will be taught how to have all cores take part in a single task, or to have each core working on its own share of the total task.

Modern day researchers quite often have to rely on larger systems than their own. In the Netherlands many use the national supercomputer clusters, Lisa and Cartesius, at SURFsara. Like most other large shared computer systems in research, these systems have UNIX, or Linux, running as operating system. On top of that, many of them make use of a batch system to give multiple users a fair share of the total resources.

After working with Lisa, the different types of parallel programming will be taught with Python as programming language. Although C and Fortran are very common in high-performance computing, it is also possible to use parallelism in Python, the language of choice for many researchers in the data science field.

The contents of this course comprise a BASH (Unix shell) course, a Python recap, an introduction to Jupyter Notebooks and a programming course to learn how to work with different parallel modules and packages in Python. For the latter, the “Python Parallel Programming Cookbook” is used. Although referred to as a cookbook, it has a decent amount of theory to build a foundation for deeper understanding of parallel paradigms.

column1: Students will acquire a theoretical understanding of parallel computer architectures and of different parallel paradigms.
By the end of the course students will be able to write and run BASH shell scripts, to work with large batch systems (at SURFsara, or anywhere) and to write parallel code in Python.

column1: This seminar takes the ubiquity of digital media technologies as a starting point and aims to understand and explain how traditional roles of (media) audiences have changed. Although the Web2.0 enthusiasts are overtly positive about active user roles and applaud the online possibilities of user participation, others approach the activities of users with caution and skepticism. Some critics claim that self-publishing undermines our sense of what is true and what is false and corrupts our culture.

The central topic of this seminar is the reconfiguration of the traditional consumer/producer relationship in the online media domain. Theoretically, the approach is informed by different approaches. The Social Shaping of Technology perspective, the concept of spreadability and Uses and Gratifications theorizing provide prominent and specific interpretative focuses. In class, we will study and critically assess these different theoretical perspectives on participation.

The selection of compulsory literature contains sources that have attained a classical status (e.g., O’Reilly, 2005) and sources covering contemporary theoretical and practical developments. Cases are on purpose chosen from different periods aiming to advance theoretical understanding.

Students are expected to critically engage with the theoretical matter and actively participate in and contribute to an open and inspiring learning environment. Individual engagement is combined with team efforts through mini lectures, and poster presentations. The classroom is partially ‘flipped’ by means of quiz questions supplied on Canvas.

• The value of different theoretical perspectives on (participating) online media users.
• The value of empirical research on new media users.
• The ways in which scientific knowledge can be applied to a relevant case study.
• Analyze recent and future trends in new media usage.
• Reflect critically on the claims made by researchers and theorists from different perspectives.
• Take and defend different theoretical positions.
• Independently analyze an empirical case study.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This third course in the Politics & Society specialisation focuses on the political relevance of different types of globalisation for political parties, governments, and domestic and international policy. First, we focus on the new challenges that political parties face due to globalisation. It inspires their reconsideration of actions, strategies, and guiding principles, poses threats to some of these, while it provides opportunities for other ones. Hotly debated topics that will be addressed in this course are questions such as whether globalisation explains the rise of new populist parties, whether it leads to fragmentation of the party landscape, and whether it affects party ideologies. Second, contemporary governments have to deal with all abovementioned aspects and political corollaries of globalisation. The general question is how governments behave in a globalised context. Governments and their constituting political parties increasingly have to navigate between the often conflicting demands of their constituency and international obligations, such as those stipulated by the European Union (EU). Do they, for instance, pursue a politics of austerity as agreed upon in response to the European financial and debt crises, and consequently reform the welfare state? And how do governments respond to other globalisation-related issues, such as immigration and asylum applications? Do governments become less generous? And what role do party ideology, party competition, public opinion, NGO’s, and business interests play in the process?

Third, we discuss the increased impact of supranational organizations like the EU, transnational networks and civil society organizations on citizens and policies. How do international organizations like the EU try to resolve social problems such as unmanaged mass migration, terrorism and climate change? How do citizens perceive the EU and what factors explain the differential support for EU integration across individuals and countries? Moreover, does public opinion and the changing party landscape affect the EU and its institutions as well?

Note: This course builds on theories, concepts, and research findings discussed in the first two courses in Politics & Society (that is, The Social Bases of Politics and Political Attitudes and Behaviour in Context). We allow up to five elective students. Students who have at least attended one and preferably both of the two prior courses in Politics & Society are eligible to apply. Selection will be based on both prior knowledge and motivation. Note that basic knowledge of quantitative social-scientific methods is needed in order to understand a substantial part of the mandatory literature.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Differentiate among the types and aspects of globalisation processes taking place;
• Explain social-scientific theories on how globalisation influences party systems, party ideologies, and government behaviour;
• Explain social-scientific theories on the way in which governments and policies related to global issues are influenced by tensions between domestic politics and international obligations;
• Apply the above-mentioned social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalisation and politics to contemporary politicalhenomena;
• Discuss the similarities and differences between social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalisation and politics;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the relationship between globalisation and politics;

• Formulate and test a theoretically informed hypothesis related to the impact of globalization on political institutions and/or government policies by conducting a basic quantitative analysis of secondary data;
• Orally present the findings of the above-mentioned analysis to an informed audience.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: “But why can’t I patent in Europe just because I talked about the invention at a conference?” “But I thought the claims in my patent would stop my competitor marketing that product!” “I invented an improvement! So why do I have to get a licence from them before I can market my own invention?” “So I would have been better off just keeping this process secret rather than patenting it?”

Intellectual property is a vital asset for firms today, and patent portfolios can be extremely valuable. Yet all too often managers know little about patent law and patent strategies. This ignorance can be costly, because a naïve manager is like a lamb going to the slaughter-house. Skilful competitors will slice and dice a poorly worded patent that is in their way, or use a variety of other patent strategies to hinder the goals of their less knowledgeable and less experienced counterparts.

This elective combines theory and practice. The course starts with an overview of all forms of IP, as managers need to be able to identify all the different sorts of IP that can attach to one product. It then briefly examines the basics of patent law; what is not patentable and the problems associated with patenting AI and software; the patent application with particular attention to patent claims and what constitutes patent infringement. We will look at how patents have increasingly become a strategic weapon rather than just a means of protecting an invention from imitation. With Sun Tzu’s ‘Art of war’ as a guide, we will look at the different strategies businesses use.  Patenting is not, however, always the best option. Alternatives to patenting will also be examined.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: “Companies’ biggest assets today are intangible ones like patents. And that’s true not just in technology intensive industries…IP savvy business leaders believe that, in a world where battles are increasingly being waged not for control of markets or raw materials but for the rights to new ideas and innovations, the management of intellectual property must become a core competence of the successful enterprise.” (Rivette and Kline in Harvard Business Review).

They are right. It is time that understanding intellectual property (IP), and in particular patents as the most expensive form of IP, became a ‘core competence’ of any graduate from a business school. Patents have become a strategic business tool and every manager has to know how to use that tool and how it will be used against you. So if you think understanding about patent law and strategy is only a matter for inventors, technicians and lawyers, you are very badly mistaken. Today it is more often the managers of a firm, rather than the R&D department that makes decisions about IP. Every manager in every firm needs to be aware of how IP impacts upon business.

The aim of this elective is to make sure students are prepared for management in a business environment that is increasingly dominated by IP. It will provide students with insight into some of the legal and practical issues that arise when firms use the inventions of others or wish to protect their own inventions. After this course, students will understand the basics of patent law and patent claims, how patents are used as a strategic tool of competition, and when patenting is not the best alternative.

This course aims to provide students with a thorough understanding of the underlying mechanisms of heart diseases. The students will be able to integrate the information acquired in other disciplines such as Life Support, Human Anatomy, and Human Physiology. The general approach to study the different diseases will include four essential components: cause/aetiology, mechanisms of development (pathogenesis), structural alterations of cells (morphologic changes), and the consequences of changes (clinical manifestations). During this course, students will also learn skills that will help them to structure the acquired knowledge in a clinical context.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of this course is to acquire a basic knowledge of the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases affecting the heart. At the end of this course, you will:

column2: • have obtained fundamental knowledge about the pathology and pathogenesis of diseases within the domains of cardiology.
• describe, distinguish and analyze how specific diseases affect the function of the heart, disrupting the homeostasis of the organism (pathophysiology);
• explain why particular symptoms are presented in patients with these diseases;
• know how to apply diagnostic tools and clinical skills;
• distinguish and evaluate the different available therapeutic approaches for the various diseases.

column1: In this course, the students will integrate the knowledge obtained in the previous Pathology and Pathogenesis courses. They will learn about the role of the endocrine system in maintaining homeostasis, and they will be able to describe how the secretion of hormones is regulated, and how disruption of the normal physiology can lead to different diseases. Finally, the students will develop the ability to evaluate, treat and monitor common endocrine disorders, and also familiarise themselves with less common endocrinological afflictions.

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

</style>

column1: During the course 'Patient Centred Care Delivery' (PCCD) students will be taught the most important theories, recent systematic reviews and empirical findings regarding PCCD. During the last decade more and more attention has been given to PCCD; organisations aim to deliver care that is patient centred in order to improve patient outcomes. Evidence indeed has shown that PCCD results in improved health, health behaviour, and quality of life of patients as well as their family/caregivers. Still, evidence is inconclusive and organisations and professionals are generally unknowledgeable and struggle on how to improve PCCD and support interaction between professionals and patients in such a way that it stimulates co-care delivery between them (week 1).
During the second week attention will be given to various forms of interactions between professionals and patients and legal aspects of informed consent and shared decision making

(week 2). Behind every professional there is a team that influences quality of care delivery to patients. Nowadays with an astonishing rise of chronically ill patients and multi-morbidity patients professionals are dealing with patients with complex and multiple needs. These changing needs from acute to chronically ill patients ask for a different approach from organisations regarding their care delivery. Interprofessional collaboration is needed to support the needs of these patients, which requires communication and coordination between professionals from various occupational backgrounds and a supportive team climate (week 3). In turn, effectiveness of these teams is influenced by the culture, structure and availability of resources within the larger organisation. Also leadership affects interprofessional collaboration between professionals and in turn quality of care delivery to patients (week 4). In order to create co-care delivery between professionals and patients diversity in care delivery is needed. Just as professionals operate within a team and organisational context patients are influenced by their environment as well. Patients differ in their educational level for example, their ability to self-manage their well-being and in coping with their disease or illnesses. Special attention will be given to the continuing rise of socioeconomic health inequalities and how culture influences effectiveness of care delivery (week 5). Patients are not only influenced by their individual/personal environment, but by their neighbourhood context as well, especially in regard to improve healthy lifestyles and active and healthy ageing. In the final week we will discuss the role of neighbourhoods and innovative solutions in the community (e.g. community health nurses, collaboration between health, social care and informal networks on PCCD and patient outcomes) (week 6).
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>
• Students can list the important theories and conceptual models concerning PCCD.
• Students can use theories, concepts, instruments and models from the scientific literature to explain how organisation of care delivery and interprofessional collaboration contributes to PCCD.
• Students will have a proper understanding of Shared Decision Making (SDM). They can also argue its pros and cons compared to other medical decision-making models.

• Students can explain the shift from acute to chronic care and how this leads to changing demands of patients, changing roles and expectation of patients (e.g. having a more active role, self-care and self-management) and that this requires different interaction between professionals and patients, and a different approach in the organization of care delivery to improve PCCD.

• From theories and empirical evidence students can explain how socioeconomic status and culture influences effectiveness of care delivery and convincingly defend that diversity in care delivery is needed to improve patient outcomes and enhance PCCD.

• From theoretical frameworks, conceptual models and innovative solutions students can clearly explain the role of neighbourhoods in health, health behaviour and quality of life of community-dwelling people, especially concerning age-friendly communities to stimulate healthy and active ageing among community-dwelling older people.

</style>

column1: Most organizations today collect a wealth of data that could help improve employee performance. Still, only few succeed in using this data to improve business results. People Analytics could potentially fill this void.

People Analytics constitutes the analytic approach to and statistical analysis of Human Resource (HR) and workforce data to the benefit of employee performance and the organization’s return of investment on human capital. The phenomenon gained traction in recent years, as a movement that could evolve the way we make decisions concerning people-management. It seeks to add value to organizations by leveraging analytical processes, a broad range of statistical techniques, and novel data sources. Moreover, where the returns of investment on human capital have traditionally been considered opaque, People Analytics could potentially reveal the bottom line of HR practices, interventions, and investments.

In this course, you learn how Human Resource Information Systems and People Analytics can be used to improve business outcomes and make better management decisions. Through a sequence of readings, lectures, cases, and experiential exercises, you learn what questions to ask, how to determine which methods to use, and how to publish the findings or communicate ideas effectively. This should not only help those who seek to become an HR professional or change consultant, but should also help you stand out as a manager in general.

column1: Upon completion of this course, you should be able to:
•    Explain various perspectives on what People Analytics entails and the value it could provide to the organization
•    Explain the use of the dominant classes of statistical techniques used in People Analytics
•    Design solutions to issues concerning human capital that would build on Human Resource Information Systems (HRIS) and various statistical techniques
•    Critically evaluate ethical and legal issues in People Analytics research and practice
•    Convince practitioners and scholars of your theoretically sound and practical recommendations drawing from People Analytics

column1: <body>For most students, the start of their first year of university is an interesting, but hectic period. Not only will you face new exciting experiences, you may also encounter more demanding responsibilities than before. You are faced with the challenge of choosing a career path and how to develop yourself professionally, as well as the challenge of balancing your new responsibilities with different aspects of your life. To promote the attitudes and skills that help you to become more resilient to life’s demands and to develop yourself in various domains, EUC offers its students the Personal Development Track (PDT). The aim of this track is precisely to help you through the process of self-development.</body>

column1: The course consists of 4 different parts.  However, due to the nature of the content, these 4 parts do not correlate perfectly with the 4 lectures and the assignments.
Part 1: Interview strategy, your story, your aspirations

During the 1st lecture, we will develop the concept of strategy for a job interview and explore one of its key components: how to tell your overall story.  In the associated homework assignment, you will reflect on your motivations, strengths and personality traits to try & articulate a possible career direction - all of which should be the basis for the other part of the assignment: a first draft of your story.
Part 2: Tell me about a time when...

In the 2nd lecture, we will explore how to recount in story-like manner your meaningful personal and professional experiences.  In the associated 2nd and 3rd assignments you will develop a portfolio of powerful stories that you can share as you navigate through your job search and the recruitment process.

In the 3rd lecture, we will explore various high impact tools to help you build your network by connect with unknown people eager to help.  You will learn how to reach out and how to conduct impactful conversations with them so that you can get advice from them and learn about the market and opportunities.  In the associated assignments you will develop a list of target organizations, conduct a networking conversation with a “mentor” and learn how to reach out to strangers to ask for help.

In final, lecture, we will complete our exploration of interview strategies.  In particular, you will learn about the non-story aspects of job interviews. In the associated assignment you will develop an interview strategy for a potential interview with one of your target employers.

Although course attendance is not compulsory, it is strongly recommended for ALL lectures.  Satisfactory completion of the Assignments will require a detailed understanding of concepts that will be discussed during class and that the materials alone cannot cover.  Out of respect for your fellow classmates and faculty, plan to attend sessions in full from beginning to end: joining late and leaving early are not acceptable options.
The course is pass/fail and offers the possibility of resit in its entirety.  However, there will not be an opportunity to individual assignments.

column1: What would you say if you could approach the job search process with clarity of purpose, confidence and knowing both how to secure interviews and thrive in them?  The overall objective of this course is to provide you cutting-edge tools and methodologies to:

column2: • Find out what makes you uniquely attractive as a job candidate
• Decide what you want to do
• Build a network of people eager to help you
• Learn about the less visible job opportunities
• Secure job interviews
• Pass interviews

column1: By the end of this course you will be able to:

column2: • Identify your career-relevant strengths, traits, values and motivations
• Build and engage professional networks to obtain advice and identify career opportunities
• Use the art of storytelling to talk about yourself, your past experiences and your professional aspirations in multiple recruiting contexts such as networking and job interviews
• Develop job interview strategies and execute them

column3: In dit blok staan persoonlijkheidsstoornissen en identiteitsstoornissen centraal. Er zal eerst gekeken worden naar het onderscheid tussen normale persoonlijkheidstrekken en persoonlijkheidsstoornissen. Persoonlijkheidsstoornissen vormen een aparte as binnen de DSM-V en kunnen worden onderverdeeld in drie clusters. Cluster A bestaat uit de paranoïde, schizoïde en schizotypische persoonlijkheidsstoornis. Cluster B omvat de antisociale, de borderline, de theatrale en narcistische persoonlijkheidsstoornis. Tot cluster C worden de ontwijkende of vermijdende, de afhankelijke, de obsessief-compulsieve of dwangmatige persoonlijkheidsstoornis gerekend. In dit blok zal dieper worden ingegaan op het klinisch beeld, de diagnostiek en de behandeling van bovengenoemde stoornissen. Daarnaast zal in dit blok ook aandacht worden besteed aan de rol die identiteit speelt bij persoonlijkheidsstoornissen. Tevens zullen de dissociatieve stoornissen en genderidentiteitsstoornissen aan bod komen. Tot slot zal er middels een opdracht ook aandacht worden besteed aan impulscontrole stoornissen. Ook hierbij staan wederom het klinisch beeld, de diagnostiek, de behandeling en actuele theoretische inzichten centraal.

In dit blok wordt door middel van twee opdrachten dieper ingegaan op relevante onderwerpen. Ten eerste zal middels een blokopdracht aandacht worden besteed aan stoornissen binnen de impulscontrole. Tevens zal er middels een blokopdracht aandacht besteed worden aan zelfreflectie door middel van het invullen en interpreteren van de Young Schema Questionnaire (YSQ).</body>

column1: <body>Today, personality psychology and research into the differences between individuals forms an important fundamental basis for the daily practice of psychologists. Psychologists select people for jobs in corporate life based on personality research. If psychologists treat psychological disorders, they often collect information on a patient’s personality. Personality psychology research is therefore an important basis for every student who wants to work in such diverse fields as clinical research, forensic psychology, or human resource management etc. The course Personality Psychology examines the patterns of thoughts, feelings and behaviour that make a person unique but at the same time similar to others. In doing so, the course provides students with a broad introduction into the major themes that govern Personality Psychology.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column5: In dit blok richten we ons op de thematiek van personeelswerving, -selectie, classificatie en plaatsing. Theorieën en technieken komen aan bod voor het effectief passen van individuele behoeften, voorkeuren, kennis, capaciteiten en vaardigheden, met de behoeften en voorkeuren van de organisatie. We besteden onder meer aandacht aan voorspellings- en besluitvormingsmodellen tijdens selectie. Voorts gaan we in op utiliteitsmodellen, anti-discriminatiemodellen, klinische en statistische predictie, en validiteitsgeneralisatie. Onderwijsgroepsbijeenkomsten hebben de vorm van het maken van opdrachten die gerelateerd zijn aan bovenstaande thema’s nadat deze zijn behandeld tijdens college. Het bijwonen van de colleges is van cruciaal belang voor de onderwijsgroepen.

column1: Als professional in de zorgsector zet je je in voor anderen. Om dit op een betrokken en bewuste wijze te doen, is het van belang dat je jezelf goed kent. Met meer inzicht over jezelf en je eigen handelen, maak je namelijk professionele en persoonlijke keuzes die beter bij je passen. De Persoonlijke- en Professionele Ontwikkelingslijn (PPO) helpt te ontdekken hoe je jouw (zelf)kennis het beste in de echte wereld kan toepassen en, als uniek persoon, een verschil kan maken in de zorg.

In het eerste studiejaar ligt de focus van de PPO-lijn vooral op het ontwikkelen van professioneel gedrag. Hierin wordt gefocust op het stimuleren van actieve participatie aan de onderwijsonderdelen en het ontwikkelen van vaardigheden om meer verantwoordelijkheid te kunnen nemen voor je eigen leerproces. Dit alles zodat je kunt groeien als student en toekomstige professional.

VT Reckers - Droog', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'LGM Bremmers', 'prof.dr. MPMH Rutten - van Molken', 'prof.dr. PHM van Baal', 'RJSD Heine, MA', 'YH Chen, MSc']",,"Inhoud

column2: <title></title>
<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" />

column1: A pharmaceutical pricing strategy is more than simply setting a price to recover R&D investments and adding a mark-up to guarantee a desired profit level. Indeed, a price has often little to no relationship to manufacturing costs in this market. It is the perceived value of a new drug in a broad sense, and how a drug is positioned in the market, that is critical to its success. Especially now that development costs are growing, blockbusters are being displaced by niche drugs, treatment is increasingly personalized, and governments are limiting expenditure on healthcare. For a pharmaceutical company, getting sufficient returns on investments and keeping the pipeline filled becomes increasingly challenging.

Many pharmaceutical companies have shifted their focus from sales and marketing to strategic pricing and market access. This has been accompanied by a shift from a product-centered culture to a disease service-centered culture. Clinicians remain important decision makers, but they must move within the boundaries set by payers. Payers are now the ultimate and most influential clients of the pharmaceutical industry.

The course Pharmaceutical Pricing and Market Access (PPMA) aims to provide students with a detailed understanding of this complex and changing market. We will follow each step of the life cycle of a drug, from phase II clinical trials up to post-launch, integrating both market access theory and examples from the real world. We will discuss the importance of optimizing product launches, real world post marketing studies and innovative pricing agreements. Students will gain insight into how the latest changes in regulations, guidelines and stakeholders in the major EU, US and BRIC countries impact the success of brands, as well as the interactions between all the actors on the markets. They will learn to understand how differences between healthcare systems impact optimizing market access for pharmaceutical products.

column2: • 12 interactive lectures with plenary discussion (2 lectures of 3 hours each per week)

• 6 small workgroup meetings (2 hours, once per week) with 10 to 15 students using Problem Based Learning to formulate learning goals, exchange knowledge and have discussions about the case of the week. Problem Based Learning is an active way of learning that gives you better retention of knowledge, enhances your motivation and encourages you to develop skills that are essential for the labour market in the 21st century.
• 2 meetings in which small groups of (around 3 to 4) students present a business case and debate about the presented market access strategies

column1: The written examination is 73% of the final grade. The remainder derives from the two presentations on the business cases (10% of the final grade for each case) and attendance of the workgroups (7%).

The presentations of the business cases are scheduled in the third and sixth week and the students’ presence is obligated. The minimum pass-threshold for the weighted average of the grade is 5.5. No reading materials and notes are allowed during the exam, other than an English dictionary. A calculator is allowed.
The re-sit is composed as one single written examination that comprises the entire course learning goals and thus counts for 100%.There is no re-sit of the business case presentations.

column1: <body>By the end of the course students will:

column2: • Have insight in pharmaceutical cost and pricing trends and the drivers thereof;
• Be able to reason how the life cycle of a drug is affected by different aspects of life cycle management;
• Know how pricing and reimbursement systems of key international markets work;
• Understand key concepts of pharmaceutical innovation, pricing and market access (e.g. value based pricing, price referencing, market access arrangements);
• Be able to develop a pricing and market access strategy for drugs;
• Understand how the market for medical devices differs from the drug-market.
• Be trained in Problem Based Learning, public speaking and debating the topics mentioned above

column1: Issues in the methodology of economics, such as how unrealistic models can (and should) be and how we can appraise their explanatory power, and issues in ethics of economics, such as the goal of economic policy, but also issues of inequality, distributive justice and the moral limits of markets, are discussed in the lectures. In five tutorials, ethical issues in business and in the market are discussed and analyzed. By active engagement with these topics, students develop a stronger moral sense and they familiarize themselves with theoretical frameworks that enable them to form their own considerate opinion.

By active engagement with these topics, students develop a stronger moral sense and they familiarize themselves with theoretical frameworks that enable them to form their own considerate opinion.</body>

column1: As the Black Lives Matter movement seeks to rewrite the history of colonialism and populist politicians demand a new Renaissance, contemporary culture wars increasingly come to revolve around history. But what is history? What is, for example, ‘progress’, what remains of it, and what comes after? And who is the subject of history, the global proletariat, Western Man, or Gaïa? And who, then, is its ‘object’? Who are the winners of ‘the process of civilization’ and who are its losers? What does it mean to let bygones be bygones? And how is history intertwined with capital and technology?

Our understanding of history plays a key role in our self-understanding of as social beings. From Antiquity to the present, philosophers have therefore offered theories of history, explaining how societies develop in time. Do they progress or regress, or do they develop in endless cycles, perhaps even in a chaotic, non-linear fashion? Can history be rationalized at all? In this course we investigate what role our understanding of history plays in our self-understanding as human and social beings. We focus on the development of a new understanding of history in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries in the works of Vico, Herder, Kant, Hegel, Marx, and Nietzsche, and the critical development of their thought by philosophers such as Benjamin, Adorno, Arendt, Deleuze and Guattari, Negt and Kluge

column1: The lectures and seminar-discussions will focus on the following issues:
1.         The sources of human rights law within the system of public international law.
2.         Human rights as a specific modern discourse: the complementarity of constituting state power and controlling state-power.
3.         Human rights between democracy and the Rule of Law.
5.         Facing the limits of autonomy as sovereignty.
7.         Legal, political and ethical skepticism about human rights.
8.         Current human rights questions surrounding globalisation and populism.

The teaching method will be inductive and bottom-up: ‘learning by experience’. It means that students will engage in philosophical reflection on human rights issues while studying relevant literature and by presenting and exchanging their findings in the seminar.

The discussions will be introduced, prepared and reviewed by the lecturers (master class method). By doing so, the lecturers will offer the participants a philosophical method aimed at bringing to the surface implicit normative assumptions within a human rights discourse. They will also offer them the means to question these assumptions.

column1: The overall aim of this course is to encourage and teach students to reflect critically on human rights and human rights issues, from a theoretical/philosophical perspective. More specifically, after completing the course students should be able to:

column2: • understand the history of ideas of human rights and of human rights law
• understand the difference between legal, political and ethical perspectives on human rights
• explain the main philosophical challenges of the human rights discourse
• apply these philosophical challenges to current human rights issues
• understand and apply the concepts, methods and techniques of philosophical reflection on human rights law as a condition for a decent transnational legal and political order.
