column1: In this course we will engage with the work of the well-known, but often misunderstood media philosopher Marshall McLuhan. We will read and engage with the three theses that he develops throughout his work - the extension thesis, the environmental thesis, and the anti-content thesis - as well as how these theses have influenced ways of thinking and talking about media in both popular as well as scientific discourses.
One missed session (lecture or seminar) can be compensated for with an extra written assignment on the content/topics addressed in the missed session.
Only one session can be compensated for in this way. More than one missed session means that the student will not be able to complete the course.</body>

column1: Within the different (inter)disciplines of media- and visual cultural studies there exist a range of approaches to the interpretation and analysis of images and other media contents. Consider for instance semiotics and deconstruction in literary studies, formal and cultural analysis in film studies, iconography and composition in the study of art and quantitative and qualitative discourse analysis in studies of mass media and social media. These approaches share a tendency to “look through” media in order to focus on the image and other visual contents.

The course Philosophy of Media: Beyond the Image invites students to not only look through media as so many windows on the world – but to also take a critical media philosophical look at media in order to conceptualize media as driving forces behind large scale historical changes and a wide range of developments in our contemporary world.
The course is structured around the media philosophical strands of media ecology (both in the various European and Canadian traditions) and media archaeology (in the Nordic tradition) and
focuses on the philosophical implications of canonical texts by authors such as Roland Barthes, Walter Benjamin, Marshal McLuhan, Friedrich Kittler, Donna Haraway and N. Katherine Hayles.

In weekly tutorials as well as lectures, film screenings and site visits to media labs, students explore topics such as the relationship between technology and human agency, media as extensions of  the human body and the central nervous system, mediacentric historiographies and media archaeologies, as well as the social, cultural and political implications of various media ecologies from the past, present and future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Describe and explain the various histories of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Understand the basic tenets of the political economic and STS perspectives on Social Media;
• Critically evaluate the organizational ecologies and business models of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Critically evaluate the ways in which social practices and social media interfaces are co-constituted;
• Formulate a personal standpoint concerning the debates about the ‘effects’ of social media in domains such as privacy, creativity, copyright, distraction, sharing and sociability.
• Write and present a conference research paper.

column1: The course Methodology of Management Science focused on the selection of appropriate research methods for the scientific analysis of managerial issues. This Philosophy of Science course not only addresses deeper philosophical questions of how scientific research as a human activity may track the truth about ‘organisational reality’, but also has the aim of providing a conceptual apparatus to understand and evaluate the assumptions and truth claims of the many different theories that exist in the field of management. Management is an interdisciplinary field, and therefore harbours different theories that explain management reality using different concepts and relying on very different assumptions. Sometimes theories in management even give incompatible accounts of the same phenomenon. For both researchers and future managers it is important to be able to make a reasoned choice between the theories that apply to a specific phenomenon. This course not only seeks to provide students with the conceptual apparatus that is relevant in choosing between different theoretical perspectives, but also aims to develop the critical abilities of students to analyse and evaluate theories in management.

column2: <title></title>
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
</style>

column1: The principal objective of this course is to equip students for evaluating and choosing between the many different theories in the field management. Questions that will be addressed during the course include:

column2: • What is the difference between theories and concepts, on the one hand, and facts and empirical research on the other?
• To what extent can and should theories in social science be based on facts and empirical research?
• Should there be room for concepts and theories that do not reduce to facts and observations?
• If we accept non-empirical concepts and theories in social science, how do we establish their validity?
• What are the assumptions of theories in management, and to what extent are these assumptions scientifically acceptable?
• Should we look only at behaviour in social science, or do human intentions also matter in explaining social reality?
• To what extent can social science be value free?
• Can social science say something sensible about normative questions, or should social scientists remain silent about normative issues?

column1: After completing this course, the student has developed the following skills:
Analytical thinking, Argumentation, Theory choice, Academic integrity, Academic writing skills.</body>

column1: Although ignorance is the engine of science, turning general, philosophical wonder into a specific, well-defined research problem, is a very complex, demanding skill, that one can and should actually acquire. Building on insights from the history and philosophy of science, this course discusses and illustrates several methods to define and re(de)fine research problems stepwise, and invites students to reflect critically and creatively about the prerequisites, the powers and the limits of problem solving in both their own discipline and in interdisciplinary contexts.

column1: This course is about philosophical problems that emerge from medical research and practice. Scientific knowledge is often understood as the inexorable product of careful observation, which reveals how things really are. Science itself is often presented as having a (i.e. only one) method, which can reveal such truths. Evidence-based medicine is presented as the application of the scientific method to medicine, in which the truth about treatment effectiveness and the accuracy of diagnostic tests is revealed through careful observation.

The course begins by making a rapid historical survey of different philosophical approaches to doing science taken by canonical researchers in medicine, biology, chemistry and physics. This reveals that a great variety of different methods have been employed to produce scientific knowledge. Insights from this survey are used to identify philosophical assumptions embedded in contemporary medical research and practice.

Evidence-based medicine holds empirical observation in especially high regard, downplaying the importance of theoretical speculation. As the historical survey shows, this was not always the case. Evidence based medicine will be presented as a the latest iteration in a centuries old debate about the relationship between theory and observation. Using contemporary philosophical debates about its strengths and weaknesses, evidence-based medicine will be put ""on trial""; with some students being asked to argue in its favour, and others against it.

The course then turns its attention to the evaluation of diagnostic tests, especially to the problems that arise when trying to evaluate a test when there is no reference standard to determine disease status. The course will consider if it is even possible to make observations of disease status without theoretical expectations, and, if it is not, how it is that knowledge differs from belief.</body>

column1: <body>This course replaces last year's course 'Human Enhancement'.

column2: • This course introduces the student to philosophical problems that emerge from medical science and practice.

• At the end of the course, the student is aware of the great variety of different approaches to scientific research that have been employed by physicists, chemists, biologists and medics historically and today.

• The student can describe these different approaches using philosophical language; including ontology, epistemology, empiricism, rationalism, theory, observation, deduction, induction, and abduction.
• The student can outline philosophical positions in the debate on evidence-based medicine, particularly on determining the best methodology to evaluate the effectiveness of treatments.

• The student can outline philosophical problems associated with the evaluation of diagnostic tests, particularly regarding how to evaluate diagnostic tests when there is no accepted reference standard.
• Students are able to offer their own views about how to cope with these philosophical problems.

column1: This course is part of cluster 2. Environment, Life and Technology

Starting point is Hegel’s dialectics of scientific experience, focussing on two key text: the introduction to the Phenomenology of the Spirit and to Volume I of the Encyclopaedia of the philosophical sciences. Subsequently, we will discuss how this was taken up by later authors (Engels, Bachelard, Heidegger, Lacan, Butler, etc.). Finally, the question is whether these concepts and methods allow us to come to terms with contemporary technoscience, and vice versa: how can contemporary technoscientific developments revivify / reveal the added value of continental methods and approaches?

column1: <body>As sessile organisms, plants must be able to interpret and respond to their environment to grow and survive. They also live on a different time scale than animals, and even though their life is highly complex and often surprising, most of it is invisible (or still unknown) to humans. This course will therefore teach you the basics of plant biology, including plant structure and morphology, metabolism, reproduction, genetics, evolution and systematics. The main goal of this course is to remove all vestiges of zoocentrism from your mindset, giving you the tools to appreciate the uniqueness and specificities of the Plant Kingdom. You will be able to (i) distinguish the plants from other life forms, (ii) understand how a plant is structured, and which modifications have evolved to cope with the different terrestrial environments, (iii) describe the different parts of a plant by using appropriate botanical terms, (iv) discover why plants are the life sources for food and oxygen for all organisms on Earth, (v) understand the significance of the diplobiontic life cycle of plants, and (vi) appreciate the intricate biochemical and signalling networks of plants, including those of photosynthesis, hormone action and communication with other plants and organisms. Finally, the students will be introduced to the richness of plant diversity resulting from eons of evolution, and to enter a natural area and distinguish the plants encountered as being either Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms or Angiosperms. The course will be supported by extra activities, such as a visit to a botanical garden.</body>

column1: This course highlights the pivotal role of plants on our lives on one side, and the importance of sustainable agriculture in the food production sector on the other side. The first part of the course aims at integrating descriptive knowledge of plant anatomy and morphology with biochemical and genetic mechanisms, in order to study functional processes ranging from seed germination to flowering and fruit set. It also focuses on the study of plant processes - how plants grow, develop and function as they interact with their physical (abiotic) and living (biotic) environments. Based on this acquired knowledge, the second part of the course will focus on agro-ecology and sustainable agriculture in order to give the students an overview about the current systems of plant production and the development of novel sustainable farming systems, from soil management to fertilisation, and from the application of pesticides/herbicides to the use of GMOs. During the course, up-to-date case studies will be presented in order to illustrate how the knowledge of plant ecophysiology and agro-ecology can be a useful tool to cope with increasing environmental and societal issues, such as climate change, food production, sustainable agriculture and environmental pollution.

column3: 2. Discover what is new in plant physiology.
Like most areas of biology, plant physiology is
experiencing an explosion of new discoveries and new ideas. We will discuss some of the
new topics in plant physiology and why they are considered important.
3. Understand that plant physiology relates to other fields in biology.
be plant physiologists. For this course to be valuable to you, you must understand how plant
physiology interconnects with agricultural, forestry, environmental science, genetics, the
health sciences, and other fields. Throughout the course, connections between plant
physiology and other areas of knowledge will be emphasized.
4. Focus on how plant physiology will shape the future.
As students, you must consider the
future and your role in it. Plant biotechnology is putting plants to many new uses and
improving them for old ones. Plants can now be used to grow plastics and fuels, to remove
toxic wastes from soils, and to produce vaccines and drugs. Agriculture and forestry practices
have been altered by new crop varieties that resist stress, pathogens, herbicides, and postharvest
losses. These developments in plant biotechnology are derived from knowledge of
plant physiology and plant genetics. As scientists, business people, teachers, consumers,
voters, and parents, you must contribute to intelligent decisions about how plants should be
used to improve the human condition. To prepare you for this, we will discuss the role of
plant physiology in the future throughout the course.</body>

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Governments try to deal with complex issues, like flood protection, regeneration of urban neighborhoods, and the care for the young and elderly citizens. The context of these issues is often complex and dynamic. If contexts change, the issues changes. The straight forward and top down  implementation of a policy programs very often fail as many cases show. l. Policy initiatives and policy programs than evaporate without acceptable results. Where and why do governments end up in this kinds of inertia? However, other cases show the opposite. Where and why have other governments been able to deal with changing conditions in a more appropriate way and even use ‘the coincidences of change’ to achieve desired results? Why has policy innovation been realized?

This core course of the master in Public Administration Rotterdam elaborates why policies mainly based on political and governmental desires without a systematic understanding of the complex context will often not solve the issue it is dealing with. We clarify how and why supply-oriented policy approaches create all kinds of implementation deficits. In order to deal effectively with complex issues policy makers have to increase their understanding of the complex contexts of issues. The course helps students to make system analysis, based on several theoretical approaches of complexity. Central theoretical concepts are co-evolution, feedback and self-organizing capacities

Successful implementation urges for the &nbsp;connection of the development of policy programs with the real life worlds of citizens and semi public and private sector companies. We present an implementation oriented design of innovative policy programs. The coproduction of public and private organizations together with citizens, NGO’s and knowledge institutes can be improved by process design. Vital networks and chains are needed for effective process design.</body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The module presents a complex system perspective on governance environments and policy development and implementation processes. Policy processes evolves by positive and negative feedback, by co-evolution of processes and interactions in its context and by self-organizing capacities.

• The module increases your understanding of complexity and the inherent challenges in governing complex governance processes. What explanations does complexity theory generate for success and failure of large-scale policy programs? As a result you  will increase your capacities to apply complex system analysis.

• The module will also increase your abilities to cope with complexity. We will elaborate several implementation-oriented approaches for designing and redesigning policies: the formation of joint action in policy chains, the ability to organize reversed chain approaches starting bottom-up and coproduction in complex systems and networks.
• Elaborating modern governance and public sector innovation approaches: facilitating, smart small scale interventions, coproduction and meta-governance strategies in complex systems
• Applying methods and techniques for analyzing policy chains, public sector innovation and meta-governance
• High quality reflections on strength and weaknesses of the approaches presented.

column1: <body>The course will focus on the functioning of the markets for labor, education and health which typically are non-standard markets with a lot of government intervention. Questions that will be addressed are:

column2: • What are the main instruments for policy makers to improve the functioning of the markets for labor, education and health and what do we know about the effects?
• How can the government stimulate optimal investment in human capital or in health capital?
• What are the returns to investment in human capital at the individual or at the social level?

column1: This course is part of cluster 3. Subjectivity and Response-Ability

Why do people vote against their economic self-interest? What is the connection between Brexit and Trump? What motivates a lone shooter? Why do people throw themselves in the arms of authoritarian leaders like lemmings into the abyss? The rise of populism, cynicism, fanaticism and fundamentalism challenges us to reconsider the problem of ressentiment, a toxic brew of hatred, frustration, humiliation, indignation and passivity. Whereas its conceptualization dates back to the nineteenth century and has gradually dissolved in the course of twentieth century emancipatory processes, the concept of ressentiment is now making a comeback in political discourse.

The aims of this module are to explore the genealogy of this concept, to interpret the shifting political stakes that are expressed in it, and to evaluate the consistency and coherence with which it is currently put to use in public and academic discourse. We begin with a comparison of the concepts of resentment and ressentiment, relying on texts by Scottish enlighteners such as Joseph Butler and Adam Smith and comparing them to the texts on the untranslatable ressentiment (French word, German concept) one century later by Soren Kierkegaard, Fiodor Dostoievski, and Gustave Flaubert. We then proceed from a detailed reading of various texts by Nietzsche to a systematic mapping of the different ways and political contexts in which the concept has been reinvented in the humanities and the social sciences since. We study sources from philosophical anthropology, political theory, literary history, and anthropology, and rely on a diversity of philosophical methods such as psychoanalysis, post-structuralism, critical theory, and phenomenology. As we will see, ressentiment is one of those thorny issues that constantly threaten to compromise the one who speaks about it. There is no intrinsic good sense or evidency in the application of its concept and no universal criterion, but only a polemical sense. This means that the plausibility of the diagnosis of ressentiment, the real efficacy of its discursive ‘truth’, must be proven in another way than in the dialectical form of a truth judgment. It cannot be abstracted from a political drama in which it takes on a different meaning depending on who uses it. Yet even if there is no a priori rule and no final argument that can mediate or solve this drama, there is nonetheless a systematicity to be explored in it.
Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory. You must compensate for missing a class with a 300 word critical reading response on the mandatory literature within 3 days after class.

column1: The second course in the Politics & Society Master specialisation puts citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours in context: it focuses on the various institutional, cultural, and economic conditions relevant for understanding why political attitudes and behaviours differ across regions and change over time. It does so by discussing both classic and recent theories and research in relevant fields, most notably political sociology, political science, and communication science. The main institutional conditions addressed are political institutions, welfare regimes, and national media, as these prove to be crucial for understanding trends and cross-national differences in political trust, public opinion, and voting behaviour. The same goes for the cultural conditions addressed in this course, which most notably include regional and urban cultures, cultural and ethnic diversity, and religion and secularisation. The final part of the course focusses on the role of globalisation – especially its economic ramifications – for political attitudes and behaviour.

Besides providing in-depth insights into the relevance of contextual phenomena for individuals’ political attitudes and behaviour, this course stimulates sensitivity for recognizing unresolved and unexplored research puzzles. To this end, students write a research proposal on how a context condition affects a political attitude or behaviour of their choice. As such, it equips students with key knowledge and skills needed for conducting their research for their Master’s thesis. In addition, it stimulates students to: 1) analyse and critically reflect on the contents and implications of social-scientific theories and research findings; 2) discuss the application of those theories to contemporary social and political phenomena.

This course focuses on understanding and explaining the role of context for political attitudes and behaviours; it does not focus on its moral implications, nor on the moral implications of empirical research on that role.

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Explain context conditions relevant for changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;
• Explain theories that link context conditions to changes and differences in citizens’ political attitudes and behaviour;

• Apply the above-mentioned social-scientific theories on the influence of context conditions on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours to contemporary social phenomena, in a systematic and analytical way;
• Analyse the similarities and differences between social-scientific theories on the influence of context conditions on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;
• Critically reflect on social-scientific theories on the influence of context conditions on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;

• Develop a theoretically relevant research question and related discriminatory hypotheses, by systematically and analytically applying social-scientific theories on the influence of context conditions on citizens’ political attitudes and behaviours;
• Provide feedback on the work of fellow students.

</style>

column1: This course is an introduction to political economy. The basic premise of this course is that political actors have their own interest and do not automatically pursue the general interest. As a consequence the government cannot be considered as a single benevolent actor as is typically assumed in Public Finance. Instead interactions between different political actors determine the outcome of the political process. In particular we will consider the incentives of politicians, voters, media, and bureaucrats. We will see how they interact and determine the outcome and efficiency of the political process.

We will use standard mathematical analysis and game-theoretic modeling to analyze the interactions of political actors. Exercises will complement the lecture to give students the opportunity to apply the insights and practice the tools encountered in the lecture.
